name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The first item is the debate on the report by Pavel Poc, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the implementation of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 on plant protection products (2017/2128(INI)) (A8-0268/2018).

name: Pavel POC
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, we have a report on the implementation of the plant protection regulation on the table. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the European Commission and, in particular, the European Parliament's research service. It was an excellent job, we worked on this thing for more than half a year. We have become accustomed to saying that the European pesticide approval system is the strictest in the world. Yes, that's right, the system does. However, when we first reviewed its implementation, we found that, unfortunately, this system is being devalued by disrespect, circumvention, abuse, little transparency, both at our level, at EU level and at Member State level. Unfortunately, the regulation on pesticides is not fully implemented and the precautionary principle is often ignored, the current situation could easily pose a threat to the health of Europeans as well as a threat to species diversity, ecosystem or soil.  Just a few facts that this research has shown us. There are a number of products on the EU market that have not been re-evaluated for more than 15 years. The European Commission is also taking quite substantial steps in this regard, I believe that its work will be successful. Emergency authorisations, to be strictly used only in cases where plant production is at risk, are regularly misused by Member States to circumvent the classical authorisation process with potentially far-reaching health consequences. The case of neonicotinoids, which we have temporarily banned because of the health of bees at EU level, and the ban did not come into force at all in many countries because they were allowed in this way, speaks for all.  At our European level, the so-called confirmatory procedure is sometimes abused, unfortunately we get products on the market for which research is not completed, for which we do not know exactly what the consequences are, there is insufficient data. Among other things, thanks to this, we now have many herbicides on the market, the active ingredient of which is the same substance as it was in the infamous Agent Orange. For many pesticides, we do not know the long-term effects on biodiversity, we do not adequately evaluate the effect on soil, soil macro-organisms and microorganisms. We can't deal with the cocktail effect, we can't deal with long-term exposure of organisms to these substances and these consequences. However, even if everything goes perfectly, at the end of this process we have a Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed, which is more or less anonymous and does not have to be guided in principle by anything or science at all. This message is an implementation message, nothing more, nothing less. We tried to stick to the conclusions of the research study, I am a little sorry for some somewhat emotional and unfortunately false amendments. An example for all of them is the amendment of the European People's Party, which has been backed by other right-wing factions and which says that the number of pesticides available on the European market is decreasing. This is not true, the European Commission is doing a really good job in this regard and, according to the European Commission's public database, there are now twice as many products authorised in Europe as there were in 2009. This report is very well timed, its conclusions, research results and proposals can be adopted by the PEST Special Committee, which is to propose improvements to our European pesticide authorisation system. I also used its results to work on a proposal for a regulation on transparency and sustainability of risk assessments in the food supply chain. Unfortunately, this Parliament does not have a separate legislative initiative and I hope that the European Commission will help us to propose the necessary legislative amendments. Some of the shortcomings identified are already being corrected by the European Commission's proposals, and we will wait for others to be rectified. However, this report will in any case help in all other planned steps to improve this legislation.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Union. Sometimes it's like writing an essay: the subject is so interesting, there's so much to say, and then you write and write, and sometimes you can't even recognize the original core theme and the core problem.  I would like to remind you of the real issue. The real problem was: does the European authorisation and authorisation procedure meet the self-righteous objectives? And from our point of view, I have to say: three times no. It should become less bureaucratic: the objective should not be achieved. A Europe-wide zonal authorisation should be established: target not achieved. And it should become more transparent and cheaper: even since the target has not been achieved.  The main problem remains that, although we have cross-border zonal authorisation, there is still no mutual recognition of the Member States. In practice, this means that a means may be used on one side of the river in Austria, and on the other side of the river in Germany, the national authorisation is still pending with several years of delay. Here, too, we must overcome a certain national arrogance of authorisation. I simply ask that, in the rage of the debate and the issue of this key issue, we do not forget about this issue in the political debate of the day. I would also like to thank our rapporteurs and our shadow rapporteurs, some of whom have purified the report.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am delighted to attend today’s plenary session and to discuss the implementation of European Union legislation on plant protection products. Your own—initiative report will make a valuable contribution to our ongoing work on this important topic. I want to start by stressing that we share common concerns and common goals: first of all, to protect citizens’ and animal health; second, to safeguard the environment; and third, to maintain food safety. All three goals are common to all of us. We share these with Europeans, who are increasingly interested and engaged in how we produce food and want to ensure this is done in a sustainable way. This is very much the debate at the moment. In response, Europeans expect – and rightly so – policy—making to be more open, more inclusive and more transparent. We can only meet these expectations if we work together, learn together from recent challenges, and move forward together.   I also want to underline, with these expectations in mind, that the European Union has one of the strictest regulatory systems for pesticides in the world, as was just mentioned, but we see a lot of implementation difficulties. The system is based on science and requires a scientific evaluation of every active substance. The Commission has removed and will continue to remove active substances from the market if they are not safe. Let me stress that since the Plant Protection Products Regulation entered into force in 2011, 22 non-approval or non-renewal decisions have been taken, based on scientific evaluation. In fact, approval criteria are so strict that companies sometimes decide not to submit their substances for renewal because they do not expect them to pass this test. Substances expected to fall under the cut-off criteria see a particularly low rate of applications for renewal. This is a fact. The Commission does not hesitate, either, to restrict the use of certain substances – when justified – to protect non-target organisms like bees, as was just mentioned. The recent decision to ban outdoor use of three neonicotinoid substances is a good example.   This, I hope, demonstrates the Commission’s commitment – and my personal commitment – but also some of the difficulties that the Commission faces. These decisions are often challenged and sometimes do not receive the support of a qualified majority of Member States. That is true. Before the summer, the Commission proposed a ban or restriction on the use of four substances. However, none of them received the necessary support from Member States. I want to be clear that the legislation adopted by Parliament and the Council is very strict. At the same time, there is no such thing as a perfect system, so we should always look to refine it and incorporate lessons learned. I am pleased to read this own-initiative report and see it focuses on the same issues as the Commission’s ongoing Regulatory Fitness and Performance (REFIT) evaluation, which should be finalised in the first half of 2019. We are on the path to finishing our job. Another important report will be the Special committee on the Union’s authorisation procedure for pesticides (PEST Committee) report, which will be voted on in committee on 6 December and will also feed into the Commission’s analysis as we move ahead. I am waiting for the PEST Committee report. I will actually be very eager to carefully collect and actually look at all contributions on the matter, including those from various stakeholders, academia and NGOs in the first place, and the report from the Scientific Advice Mechanism (SAM). One point I need to be clear about, however, is that it is premature to envisage specific measures now. The evaluation needs to be finalised first before it can provide a solid evidence base for an appropriate course of action. This is not the only area we are working on. Both the fitness check on the General Food Law and last year’s European Citizens’ Initiative on glyphosate called for greater transparency in EU risk assessment in the food chain and greater sustainability. I have proposed that the European Union General Food Law be revised with these goals in mind. They touch on several recommendations that you make in the implementation report. The proposal also aims to increase transparency and strengthen risk communication. This is correct. I am confident that it will result in significant benefits and improve citizens’ trust and confidence. Trust in science is very important now. There is no doubt that transparency is fundamental and I am very proud to have delivered on this. I was actually recently thanked and reminded of this on this occasion by a voice in this debate. A very active leader was Mr Burtscher-Schaden. He said this sentence to me: ‘in March 2016, you stated that all studies should be disclosed because of an overriding public interest and two years after, in March 2018, you came with a strong legal proposal’. Thanks a lot. In other words, I promised and I delivered. Now it is up to all of us to move forward with our proposal. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) Committee has begun work on our proposal and the first draft report was published in July. I am pleased that the file is being handled quickly. I call on all of you to support this so that the legislative process can be finished within the current legislative term. From my point of view, it would help us to move in the right direction.  Beyond this, we are investing via research in a more sustainable future. To support the development of low-risk products of biological origin, the Commission has identified research areas under the Seventh Framework Programme and the Horizon 2020 programmes and has funded – or will fund – several projects on integrated pest management and biological control. No doubt this will take time. There is also the Sustainable Use of Pesticides Directive, which seeks to reduce the risk of pesticides to health and the environment. I know that Ms Jytte Guteland is also preparing a report in this respect and we will await its final conclusions. Last year, a Commission report found wide variations between different national action plans linked to this Directive. This needs to change for all of us. Member States are currently reviewing these plans and must include clear, measurable goals and timetables. I call on you to lead focused debates on national action plans in your own individual Member States. This would be very helpful. Thank you once again for your engagement and your report. I will follow your vote later today closely and I can assure you that your conclusions will be carefully considered in our REFIT evaluation. I look forward to continuing our joint work to improve transparency, trust and the overall sustainability of our food safety system.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and to pick up on one of the points he made about sustainability and security for citizens, for the environment and for food safety. We are all concerned about those, Commissioner, so that’s a point we took into account when we were looking at this legislation. We are also grateful to our own parliamentary research services for this rather large tome of a document, which is an impact assessment of legislation which is world class. I think we all agree with that: we have good legislation. What this report is about is making sure it’s being implemented effectively. Other colleagues have spoken about where the problems are in implementation, and they are at Member State level – a lack of coordination, perhaps a lack of trust – and they are things which can be rectified. I hope that the work of our rapporteur and colleagues in this Chamber will allow that to happen because it is really important. I know that when this legislation was first being discussed there were a lot of concerns amongst farmers because they felt they would be left with no products to keep their plants healthy, to improve yields, or whatever. And I would point out that when we say we should ban this product or that product, without saying what the alternatives are and what the consequences are, it doesn’t make us look good as legislators. So I would ask us to be very conscious of our language because – clearly, Commissioner, you are right – where a product has a problem it should not be used, but we also need to make sure that we have sufficient replacement products or systems so that farmers can manage their plant health, look after diseases and control weeds, in a way which is sustainable. I am afraid that is where we have failed because we are not reassuring those who produce our food that we have them in mind when it comes to discussions and debates and legislation on plant protection products.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, this House, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work on this very important Work psrely, and I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work on this First of all, I would like to thank our colleague Pavel Poc for his excellent work, which can really be seen as an expert in this area.  Colleagues who know me and my work from both the Committee on Health and Agriculture know that it is important to me that citizens can rely on compliance with the hazard-based approach that underpins this law when approving plant protection products. In addition, this risk-based approach was extended some time ago by another principle, the precautionary principle. In view of the fact that we want to promote sustainable agriculture within the Union and to support it accordingly in legislation and financial terms, it is important to me to create the appropriate framework conditions in the area of authorisation and use of plant protection products as well.  We boast that we have the best and safest authorisation procedure, which is also confirmed time and again in the context of the work in the Special Committee on the AUTHORISATION procedure for eu pesticides, and yet shows massive weaknesses: for example, the numerous derogations granted in the Member States under Article 53 of the opposite regulation are extremely worrying. This misuse of a plant protection product, which should only be used in emergency situations, allows rapid use of funds on our markets or allows banned products to be re-used. This simply disregards all the principles that serve the protection of the environment, human and animal health and circumvents the actual evaluation procedure.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, whatever we do and whatever agricultural model we use, the production of food is a natural thing to do. And it has an environmental impact. It is our job and the job of the sector to minimise that environmental impact.  That is why an integrated crop protection approach is so important. We need to put a lot more effort into preventing a plague from breaking out than healing. How do we do that? First of all, by breeding, to digest crops that are more resistant to diseases. By focusing more on soil quality. With ecological innovations, such as the use of insects and microorganisms, but at the same time technological innovations, such as precision agriculture, but as a last resort to ensure that the harvest is not lost. To reduce food waste, chemical agents are sometimes needed.  What is important to realise is that the admission procedure we have here in Europe for resources is the strictest in the world. What I want to go to is that the search for alternatives, low-risk resources and biological resources is accelerated, that the admissions system has specialized people for that and that there is more manpower and more money to do this. This, for example, for small crops, which do not yet have such a last resort, also makes certain resources available. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card question. – I was pleased to hear the Commissioner say that this debate should be conducted in public and that all scientific studies should be made public. Today four Green MEPs are at the European Court of Justice arguing that the Monsanto studies on glyphosate should be in the public domain. I would like to ask Mr Huitema if he agrees with the Commissioner and with me that we should make our policy on the basis of public science and that secret science is not science.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: "blue card" answer. – Thanks for the question. I also believe that science should be as guiding as possible and that we should be as transparent as possible about it.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report. This shows that the system has significant shortcomings. It is not the problem: too much bureaucracy or too expensive. On the contrary, we need to make the system better and to check it better. We can see that we have significant shortcomings in the authorisation procedure. The problem is clearly a lack of transparency. And we have the problem that Member States are not implementing properly. How can it be that we ban neonicotinoids and allow other Member States to continue to use this product on the basis of derogations? This cannot and must not happen. We also have a problem in the evaluation of substances, which must be said quite clearly, namely that environmental and beneficial insect effects are not sufficiently assessed throughout the process. We have seen it in neonicotinoids. The procedure has proved to be wrong, that 20 years later we actually notice that the environmental impact of neonicotinoids is much greater than previously thought. Therefore, yes, we are in agreement. We need to use alternatives. But you also have to invest resources in it. And we really need to make sure that we reduce the use of chemicals in the field. This cannot continue.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, this report deals with plant protection products. And that's a really crazy name for substances that aren't so much meant to protect, but especially to kill.  The Commission has a duty to ensure that only products that are not harmful to humans, animals or the environment are approved. However, the European Ombudsman concluded that the Commission is far too lenient, leaving many substances on the market unjustly. According to food watchdog Foodwatch, the Commission has been keeping hundreds of toxins on the market for years without a scientific assessment or evaluation. As a result, even a number of substances are still on the market that are proven to be harmful to health. Agricultural poison with glyphosate as a symbol shows what is wrong in Europe. Multinationals are above the environment and money, above health. The Special Committee of Inquiry into the authorisation of pesticides could put an end to this failing policy. Unfortunately, as with the Commission, the results of this investigation are not expected in this Parliament. A missed opportunity. Just as the content of this report is a missed opportunity.  Parliament had the opportunity to close back doors. Parliament had the opportunity to change an old course of action. It had the chance to stop the many gruesome animal experiments for agricultural poison. But Parliament has failed to pass up these opportunities at the expense of animals, people and the environment. The future of our planet is at stake. I therefore find it incomprehensible that Parliament has not taken these opportunities. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, Commissioner, while this report is generally relevant, I am surprised that he welcomes, and I quote: 'the Commission has come to the conclusion that the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has shown great transparency and has shared data within the confines of the rules of strict confidentiality'. I am also surprised that the text welcomes, and I quote: 'EFSA's continued efforts to improve its system to ensure its independence and the management of potential conflicts of interest'. As coordinator for my group in the special committee PEST (Eu-enforcement procedure for authorising pesticides) I have not felt the same way about EFSA, which is still at the heart of the glyphosate controversy. If EFSA copied and pasted, in this report, a hundred pages of industry and parliament has set up a special committee on the procedure for authorising pesticides, let us keep in mind that there must be reasons.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the various environmental scandals and the European Union's hesitations and reversals with regard to phytosanitary and phytopharmaceuticals such as glyphosate clearly show that the texts, even if they are European, are made to be circumvented and are therefore ineffective. The assessment of the current directive shows how the weight of lobbies is playing against Europeans and how weak our institutions are. It is clear that all conflicting studies undermine the credibility of official bodies and at the same time Member States are held back when they want to apply the precautionary and substitution principle. We must therefore apply the principles of independence and transparency as soon as possible in order to ensure our health and food security. Very seriously, the Commission's ability to improve the situation, no longer with words and incantations, but with firm decisions, is now also being undermined. This transparency and independence must also be imposed on the Commission.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report on the implementation of the regulation on phytopharmaceuticals comes at a time when the issue of pesticides is at the heart of debate in Europe. Citizens are becoming more and more attentive to what they are putting on their plates, and rightly so. In fact, part of the European distribution has followed suit and has begun to exclude some controversial plant protection products from its shelves. As parliamentarians, our role is not to give in to sirens. We must remain pragmatic, vigilant and lead a balanced path. It is our duty to ensure that the registration procedures for plant protection products are clear and transparent. Citizens have a right to know what they are eating and they need to be reassured about the food they eat. In this sense, I would like to raise a European aberration: you cannot import products grown in third countries with substances which, here in Europe, are prohibited. We cannot require our farmers and consumers to be the best students in the class while importing products that do not meet our standards and standards. This is the best way to condemn our agriculture. We need to move towards more environmentally friendly and more profitable agriculture for farmers. This is the meaning of the message I am carrying in this Parliament on the dual environmental and economic performance of European agriculture.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, 'We want poppies', this is the movement that was launched yesterday in France by personalities, scientists, artists and citizens. What do they want? They call for an immediate ban on all synthetic pesticides. It is a call from humans to other humans. We have an obligation to move forward together, in the interests of the 500 million European citizens, but also and above all - I want to say - our farmers, who are the first victims of pesticides, but who demand the same rules for all in the internal market. We have to act responsibly, but there is an urgency, and we know that. We cannot pretend that there is no problem with fertility, early puberty, as if 80% of the insects or 30% of our birds had not disappeared and as if the pollinators were not in danger of death. The European Commission, Commissioner, must apply, and we know this, the precautionary principle as provided for in Article 191, paragraph 2, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore hope that in its future proposals the EUROPEAN executive will take into account our recommendations made here, but also that our Committee of Inquiry on Pesticides, which will report its work at the end of this year, will do the same. I here solemnly wish to pay special tribute to my colleague Pavel Poc for this excellent report, which has been the result of a genuine commitment on this subject for several years now.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, as always, good legislation with good implementation is or should be applied. The report clearly shows that better implementation, enforcement and monitoring of existing legislation on plant protection products is needed. Also to avoid, as has already been said, that exceptional measures are used as a back door. The N-VA delegation supports this report. Above all, we are working to improve the use of good agricultural practices, such as integrated pest control. We certainly agree with the demand to increase transparency in procedures. That can only benefit trust. We can also count on our support for the call for research and innovation, including on biological pesticides. Finally, I would like to stress that we are and remain in favour of a scientifically based objective and evidence-based policy.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, the concern of Europeans continues to grow as crises progress, as they renounce. The glyphosate saga, it has been said, with this new five-year renewal, the Fipronil-contaminated egg crisis - it was last summer - the soap opera of neonicotinoids, bee-killing insecticides, which finally led to the banning of three of them last May. One thing is clear: pesticide legislation is not being properly enforced by Member States. The abuse of emergency authorities, in particular, must stop. In Belgium, it is the use of this procedure, provided for in Article 53, which justifies the use of a substance as dangerous to the airways as chloropicrine is still used on field strawberries. This brings us back to the application of the precautionary principle, which, I recall, is a principle of action and not an encouragement not to move, to do nothing.  Our Parliament has a compelling duty with regard to pesticides, as with other products. It must put the health of Europeans first, as proposed by the excellent report which I support, of course, from our colleague Pavel Poc.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, our natural world is facing Armageddon, with the loss of three quarters of insects and the collapse of ecosystems. According to the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), at the current rate of soil loss, we have only 60 harvests left. The chemical dependency of our farming system is the root cause of this devastation. We need to change the way we farm, not only for nature’s sake, but because we are destroying the very land we depend on for our survival.  The report we are debating highlights significant shortcomings in the approval process for pesticides and the control in their use across the EU. The Commission is handing out so—called ‘emergency waivers’ for farmers to use pesticides that we know are damaging to human health or the environment. There are also clear conflicts of interest here: with industry dictating much of the approval process, too much power is in the hands of agribusiness. Organic farmers everywhere are showing the way towards a truly sustainable farming system that provides a secure livelihood and a healthy future for all of us and for the ecosystem we depend on.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by sharing the concerns expressed by my group colleague, Mrs McKenna. Hazekamp, with regard to the progress of the PEST Committee, a committee from which we would have liked to have been able to provide elements of reassurance for the health of citizens and in which, on the other hand, it seems to us that once again politics is not really at the service of people's health. I believe that today, with this debate, we have a duty to guarantee three things: not only harmonisation, not only transparency, but the certainty that the European Parliament is working by putting the precautionary principle and the health of European citizens before any other type of interest. We have a duty to demonstrate this, and I believe that, let us say, this House is taking on an important responsibility from this point of view too with this vote. Finally, let me remind you of Fabian Tomasi, who died prematurely at the age of 53 from glyphosate, let me pay tribute to his battle against Monsanto.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: – Mr President, it is very important that we have a science—based, evidence—based approval process, and we do. This is a very rigorous process. Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 is a very robust regulation and it’s simply not true to say that the precautionary principle is clearly not being applied in the context of risk analysis regarding pesticides. No doubt, there are problems with the implementation in Member States, but the answer is not new regulation, it is actually the enforcement of the regulation we have. Too often in this place we decide we’re going to create new regulation simply because we are not properly enforcing the regulation we have. That is very bad practice and we should stop. We need to enforce the regulation we have, and a part of that regulation is the possibility of emergency uses. We need the flexibility. We cannot have a one-size-fits-all answer for the whole of the EU. We have different conditions, we have climate changes coming along, so it is not national governments flouting the regulation; it is national governments responding to the specific needs of their farmers and their agriculture, and I support that.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I disagree with Mrs McIntyre here. We have different perceptions. In the Pesticides Committee, we have recognised that the scientific methods used by EFSA are sometimes 15 years outdated. We have seen that there is in fact no research on the common effect of pesticides. If you buy and eat a conventional apple or drink a glass of wine, you have five to twenty different pesticides in it. There is, in fact, no research on this. There are new toxicological methods that urgently need to be introduced into our authorisation procedures. We are destroying our environment, we are destroying our landscape, we are destroying our biodiversity with this form of pesticide farming, which we are promoting here today from Parliament. Even the European hunting associations support us Greens in our fight for the greening of agriculture, because these are also the people who are out in the country and who see that there are no more birds, there are no more insects, there are no more rabbits. They see it, and they are now on our side. I agree with Mrs Delahaye absolutely right: products imported into the European Union must be subject to the same standards as us farmers. Because it is incomprehensible that we have this disadvantage in the competition. We need a new agricultural policy, we need a greening of agricultural policy. And I also call on the Conservatives to finally see what the order of the day is.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have listened carefully to our views and I think we all have a common point, which is that we want to have healthy agriculture. However, there is a need for change and I appreciate the rapporteur's views. Let us think only of the single european Union authorisation system required in this report. We need, Commissioner, to have a single system, and we also need to follow how this single authorisation system is implemented. Then mutual recognition doesn't work, and I think that's our job: when something doesn't work, let's take action. On the other hand, research must continue and it has been said here: when agriculture does not have a particular solution, we must find it and give it, because agriculture cannot stand still. We have a common agricultural policy and we are competing, after all, with other markets. I would not want to import from third countries and kill agriculture from the European Union, but at the same time we need to think about the harmful effects, and here we have to invest in research. You must work, Commissioner, with the Commissioner for Agriculture, and we need to see if we have thought carefully about investment in this area, because, yes, we cannot have new substances, we cannot have efficient and competitive agriculture in the global market, unless we also have an appropriate research result.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, as we have the luxury of some time, I want to respond to a sense that I’m getting from this debate, and which a lot of us would feel, that organic agriculture is portrayed as the Holy Grail, and conventional agriculture as problematic. I perceive that as a problem in itself because I know that organic farmers need to use products on occasion – let’s call them plant protection products – when there are difficulties. Equally, organic livestock farmers need to use animal health products when animals are sick. I think this division, this ideology, is unhelpful as we try to move towards sustainable agriculture, and I wish we would be less ideological in our discussions. I want to support the point made by my colleague who talked about the importation of food into the European Union, where it may be produced using products which we are banning inside the European Union. Please, Commissioner, listen carefully to that point and do something about it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, Mrs McGuinness, you are quite right: there is an intelligent form of agriculture and there are stupid forms of agriculture. There is an agriculture that is oriented towards nature and one that does not. And I am not saying that all conventional agriculture is not intelligent and is not oriented towards nature. There are also very good farms there. You are quite right: in organic farming, too, a remedy is used in an emergency, which is less toxic. Nor do I think it is a matter of dividing this. Just pretending that everything is fine in conventional agriculture, especially in agricultural agricultural agriculture – I simply cannot be part of that.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: blue-card answer. – I’m not sure what your question was. I have to say I disagree with your language. I think to use the words ‘intelligent’ versus ‘stupid’ in this debate is not helpful. Frankly, there are a lot of farmers who were up earlier than we were, trying to be intelligent farmers under very difficult circumstances. The point I make is that sometimes you need products. And please understand that conventional farmers do not want to use just any products, because they are costly, and we are working towards reducing the need to have these, but it is this ideological approach – that you cannot use any product – which will result in real problems in the food supply chain. I think we agree on most things, though perhaps not on the language.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this fruitful debate. I listened very carefully to your proposals and suggestions, especially in relation to trade. When we are discussing our trade agreements with third countries, we are very much involved in debates about the use of pesticides which are banned in the EU. It is and will always be on our agenda. Ms McGuinness rightly mentioned a less ideological approach in our debates. I was in Carcassonne a few weeks ago and had a meeting with organic farmers who were producing organic wine, and we have debates, which are not easy, about copper. Sometimes, too, I see how some are vocal about a ban on glyphosate, for example, knowing that a scientific assessment was done transparently. This is excluding the Monsanto Papers, which are always mentioned. It is not about the Monsanto Papers: it is about the possibility of really assessing the situation from an evidence-based point of view, from the precautionary principle, and about having arguments in our hands. Look, ban glyphosate and copper, and what about organic farming? What can we do? Ms McGuinness has very rightly raised questions. We need to understand the complexity of the issues and to see how we can achieve proper enforcement, implementation, control and integrated management. All this should, of course, be done in a proper manner. About the use of derogations: yes, we sent letters to those Member States because we asked the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to assess once again all the issues related to the use of such derogations in the area of neonicotinoids. We assess the situation and then we inform governments once again, especially those who use them without evidence. We are doing our job. We are not scapegoating, which is always bad, bad, bad. No! For me, as a medical doctor, there is no doubt that health is a priority, but if I am using medicines in animal health or plant health, or using medicines in treating people, I know what this means. We need to have a very balanced approach. I am, of course, ready to work together with you. We all share the same belief in achieving the goals regarding health, the environment and food safety. We need to work together to maintain and reinforce the European Union’s very stringent regulatory system for pesticides. Enforcement and implementation are the key. I assure you that we are committed to working towards greater transparency, increased trust and more a sustainable system of food production. Once again, thank you for your engagement and for your own—initiative report. We will be very sensitive to the report and we will see how it can be included in the whole picture, bearing in mind the possibility of having different assessments, and we will then propose to Parliament the further steps to be taken.

name: Pavel POC
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues for a very important discussion. Apparently a majority of this House are aware that there are problems in the EU system for pesticide approval and the implementation of this system, either at EU or Member State level. I am grateful to the Commissioner for saying that this means something to the Commission. I look forward to the next time that we cooperate on this issue.  But there is one last thing that I would say to Ms McGuinness. I am sure that you adore science and you adore facts, so you simply cannot say that the number of available active substances is getting lower. I have a table of Commission statistics here. It says, very simply, that, in 2009, 224 active substances were approved, and in 2018, 490 active substances were approved at European level. So the number of available active substances on the European market is not going down. That is simply not true. I would like you to give us the possibility to vote in a split vote against this fake fact.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – Since the entry into force of the 2009 Plant Protection Products Directive, a large number of hazardous substances have been removed from the market and others have been authorised with new effects, which are in principle less harmful to humans but have in some cases proved lethal to bees and other pollinators, such as neonicotinoids, which are incomprehensibly still authorised in cereals. Other issues that should be addressed in the new biocidal products strategy, as determined by the Directive itself, are the exclusion of substances with the capacity to cause endocrine alterations in non-target persons and organisms. This desidy in the application of this exclusion criterion has allowed the extension of the use of glyphosate, the effects of which as an endocrine regulator are demonstrated by different organizations, as is its potentially carcinogenic effect. In addition, the 'environmentally toxic' exclusion criterion which, as has been demonstrated in the case of neonicotinoids, does not appear to have been necessary, since, although extremely harmful to the environment, the use of these materials is legal, should be developed in detail. The Commission should establish a clear definition of endocrine regulator and a detailed description of toxicities to the phytosanitary environment.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Olga Sehnalová, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the dual quality of products in the single market (2018/2008(INI)) (A8-0267/2018).

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, seven long years have passed since the first interpellation between me and several other colleagues, which we responded to the first signals about double quality. Seven years after the European Commission's reply that there are different taste and price preferences in different countries, that the food is safe, so what is it. Colleagues, this is nothing less than the very essence of the functioning of the internal market. In 2013, the previous Parliament called on the Commission to look into the subject, to carry out a Pan-European survey and to evaluate the effectiveness of existing legislation. But it is only after another five years of persuasion and proof, various surveys, that there is a report on the dual quality and a clear position of the European Parliament. I would like to thank all my colleagues who have advocated over the past years that we take this highly political and symbolic issue, which speaks volumes about equality, fairness and fairness of the European internal market, seriously in the European Union. I thank all those who have helped explain the substance here, in the Commission and at the Council: that it is really not normal for a product that looks the same to consumers to have a different composition without the consumer knowing about it at first sight. That it is not a duel between lavender and violets, but a smaller content of meat or its substitutes, poorer quality of raw materials, their different quality and ratio, more different additives and so on.  What we want is for consumers not to be misled and to have the right to products of the same quality. What's weird about the requirement: Mark what's the same and different, what's different. In short: don't make consumers, excuse me for the expression, fools. Personal experience with the dual quality not only of food, but also of non-food goods has many people in our countries. That these are taste preferences? Even in infant formula? Comes. Even the direct price versus quality ratio is far from true here. I am glad that the European Commission has also rocked after Juncker's State of the Union address last year. We have interpretive recommendations on the table, a common testing methodology, money to gather more evidence. More tests are planned in the Member States. But watch out. We already have hard data, test results in laboratories of renowned universities, such as in the case of the Czech survey, in which I myself participated. It is certainly good to collect data at Union level. But that's not enough after so many years of consumer frustration. Especially when some countries where double quality has been revealed refuse to participate in a Pan-European survey.  Ladies and gentlemen, many of you will surely tell me that it is not the job of politicians to prescribe to producers what and how to produce. The aim is not to unify products, to invent a kind of uniform euro flavor. However, consumer preference must no longer serve as a pretext for quality reduction. Most consumers do not even know that products of the same brand can be adapted to different markets. If the manufacturer wants to offer the customer a regional treatment, what prevents him from proudly signing up for it on the packaging? I want accurate and easy-to-understand information about the composition of the product. That's the basis. Member States must also introduce a regulation on the cooperation of national consumer protection supervisory authorities. They must share data, point out to each other non-complying products and possible misleading consumers. The role of consumer organisations is also important. I really appreciate their daily work in monitoring the market and educating consumers. But we can't expect miracles from them.  What is most important from my point of view: there is a lack of regulation at EU level. A regulation that clearly and without the possibility of different interpretations sets out what is double quality. That selling products on the internal market that the consumer can easily perceive as identical to deliberately different compositions is misleading the consumer. A regulation that will also bring legal certainty to supervisory authorities that will not fear costly legal battles with multinational supranational companies. Not so that your favorite drink tastes the same everywhere, but so that dishonest people feel a real possibility of punishment if they don't act fairly.  Ladies and gentlemen, I believe in the honesty of most manufacturers. Yet, where they are missing, there are legislators here to support their citizens, wherever they live in Europe. With today's vote, we have a chance to show that we are on the side of a fair European Union where there are no products or second-class citizens.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the ENVI Committee. – Dear Chairman, research has shown that seemingly the same products of lower quality are often placed in eastern European Union countries. These are different products, from detergents to baby food, which can often be both of lower quality and less healthy. When I started dealing with this problem five years ago, I must admit that it seemed unlikely that today we would have such an ambitious report on the table.   The report has been endorsed by three committees and calls for a change to the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive. It also calls for the establishment of a European body to regulate the market within the existing agency.   This problem is considered very emotional by citizens of a large part of the European Union. We feel like second-class citizens. Today is the time to show that this Parliament represents all citizens, that there is no east and west and that we are all one Union. We're not all the same, but we're equals.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, of course all European consumers, irrespective of where they live, should have equal access to the same high-quality products. That is basic. This is one of the basic principles of the European Single Market. Over the past 12 months, the Commission has made decisive progress in addressing the issue of dual quality. We have worked with the Member State authorities and have provided concrete guidance on the relevant legislation, as well as co-funding for tests and enforcement capacities. The Commission’s Joint Research Centre, in close cooperation with all the stakeholders concerned, has developed a harmonised testing methodology, which is now being implemented in an EU-wide testing campaign. The majority of the Member States beyond those that have initiated and carried out tests at national level have agreed to participate in this exercise, which will provide us for the first time with authoritative and comparable evidence regarding the scope and dimension of the problem. The Commission is confident that the initial results, which will be obtained by the end of the year, will help us to define our methodology and to determine what is a significant difference noticeable to consumers when they are faced with products marketed as identical. This comprehensive action would not have been possible without the leadership that Parliament has shown, and I therefore wish to thank all of you, and in particular the rapporteur, for the excellent work that has been done and for your support. You are aware that the Commission has proposed to amend the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive in the broader context of our new deal for consumers. Allow me to thank the European Parliament and the rapporteur, in particular, for swift action on that proposal. Making consumers believe that products which are sold under the same brand, and with the same or very similar packaging, are the same across several Member States, when in fact this is not the case, is an illegal business practice. Let me assure you that the Commission remains fully committed to countering unfair commercial practices relating to the issues of dual quality of products. Our legislative package on the new deal for consumers can be a decisive step in the right direction. I therefore call on everyone in this room to support the adoption of this ambitious and important package before the elections.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Mr President, dear Olga and Bilyana, Commissioner, there will be no 'Two-Speed Europe' when there is no 'double standard against different European citizens'.  The analyses carried out in a number of countries, including mine - Bulgaria, showed that despite many years of efforts and appeals, the vicious practice of "the same product and packaging, but different content and proportions" continues. I welcome Commissioner Jourová's efforts to amend Directive 29 of 2005, but I strongly believe that the ambition of the proposal must be greater because millions of Europeans expect more. This will be done by explicitly including the ban on so-called "no-fly zones". 'double standard' in Annex 1 to the Directive.  "Local preferences" is an argument with which businesses try to address citizens' concerns. Please, that's just not wise. How can three-month-old babies determine local preferences, and why do products of a class tailored to local tastes have significant differences in their content and proportions?  It is high time that "product discrimination" against millions of Europeans from Central and Eastern Europe stopped. It is high time that the Union put all Europeans under a common denominator.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: for the PPE Group. – I consider the report on dual quality of products to be very important for all citizens. It is based on the natural principle that the same rules must apply to all in our common market. This must apply to producers, traders and, of course, to consumers. In any measure, we must bear in mind, above all, the interest of people and consumer protection. People cannot feel like citizens of the second or third category, depending on what they buy for goods under the selected brand. I am sure that the brand of goods should also be a guarantee of quality, and every serious manufacturer or seller must care about this quality. However, we are discussing today's report because there have been and are cases where this is not the case. And there aren't many. I am therefore pleased that this report has been created in the European Parliament and that it also has support in the European Commission. I see the solution, together with other colleagues, particularly in the single methodology, in assessing the dual quality of products as an unfair commercial practice and in empowering consumer organisations. Even when dealing with this subject, we do not need new institutions, but better use of existing institutions. We do not need new regulations, but greater cooperation between European and national leaders, and we do not need populism, but, above all, clear compliance with the rules. The relevant budget for testing suspicious products and better information to distinguish honest from fraudsters is also important. We cannot throw everyone in one bag, and it is also important to consider each individual case. If someone is acting dishonestly, we need to know throughout the Union. I believe that the present report is a good step towards eliminating the dual quality of products in our common market, and I would therefore like to ask for your support as approved in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Dear friend, Mr Štefanec, I am addressing you as a close friend. Why do you think all these lower—quality products were found only in central and eastern Europe? Do you not think that central and eastern European citizens should have the same rights as the citizens of other countries in the European Union?

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Yes, most cases occur in Central and Eastern Europe, but it is not entirely true that all cases are only in Central and Eastern Europe. Such cases also occur among the older Member States of the Union. That is why it is precisely important to deal with these cases, and it is important that we really have the same rules, that we follow the same quality and the same composition of products under the same quality. I am sure that this is also in the interests of all honest manufacturer-traders. We must always protect the consumer and the consumer must be informed that he must make free choices.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, a year ago in this House, President Juncker said in this House that there should be no second-class and second-class citizens in the single market.  The appeal was to those consumers who every day buy products that are marketed under the same name and packaging, but that have different levels of quality, taste and ingredients depending on the country. This is an increasingly frequent deceptive practice, which affects not only food, but also other consumer goods.  In a year we have come a long way. The legislative changes made by the Commission in the consumer package and the resolution we are voting on today recognise the importance of tackling this phenomenon as unfair commercial practice.  We certainly do not want to impose a single or identical product throughout Europe, but we want to ensure that misconduct is avoided and that consumers are properly informed.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Sehnal, not only for her excellent report, but especially for those years of patient work, without which we would not be talking here today about the dual quality of food in Europe. Although the European Commission has also gradually started to address this issue, the fact remains that national control bodies do not yet know what is already considered to be of dual quality, how to proceed when assessing products and how to address the differences identified. In fact, there is no legislation on dual quality at European level, and the European Commission's guidelines and other documents are not clear and often diverge in conclusions. While the European Commission also says that dual quality does not endanger citizens' health, it is confirmed that the individual ingredients in products in the central, eastern or southern European markets often contain less healthy alternatives, more sugar, fat or salt. I therefore fully agree with the rapporteur's view that dual quality and its assessment should finally be clearly defined and consumers should know what they are buying and also to stop feeling that the quality guarantee for the new Member States does not apply to certain brands of food and cosmetics.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the dual quality of products is a very important issue for our citizens. But it is also an important issue in terms of how the internal market works for us. It is not possible for second-class consumers to exist in the EU internal market. Consumers who are destined for lower quality products. After all, all consumers expect to purchase identical goods in the Union under the same trade mark or packaging. And so they are rightly surprised to find out that this is not the case.  We need joint and decisive action at European level, which is why I am glad that the European Commission has already presented a legislative proposal. However, we should already take advantage of the possibilities of the existing regulations and put pressure on manufacturers and traders, but also on the supervisory authorities. They must ensure the appropriate conditions for their activities and significantly intensify cross-border cooperation between them. I also consider it essential to strengthen the role of consumer organisations. These can help people when they have doubts about the quality of the goods. But the key for me is to act. Time is running out, companies should show goodwill and start taking concrete steps. We have been talking about this subject for a long time, and I just hope that we will move from words to action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Thank you for the word, greetings to the rapporteurs for the excellent work they have done.  The President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, said yesterday that there should be no differences between north and south, east and west. Is that really the case?  This is not the case in the food sector, too, because the practice and the results have shown that we have food of double quality, that products are in the same packaging with different content, and these are unambiguously unfair commercial practices that must be properly sanctioned.  We need proper control over the functioning of the market so that this so-called illicit practice does not happen, which establishes citizens of the Second Order, which in some ways, even if I say it roughly, is food apartheid.  I think that we, as Parliament and the Commission, need to put an end to this, and the vine is the excuses of producers to adapt to local preferences, because anyone can claim that some are prepared or deserve worse food, of poor quality, but that is not appropriate, of course, marked.  We therefore need sharp and precise measures.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that the dual quality of food is particularly troubling to consumers in the new EU Member States. It is demonstrable that you get products with the same brand and packaging on the market as they are sold in Germany, for example, but their quality, composition and recipe used are completely different. The consumer is therefore essentially being cheated. I find it absolutely ridiculous to make excuses that Czech consumers have different tastes or price preferences than German ones. And we're not just talking about food. Unfortunately, the same applies to cleaning or sanitary products.  I therefore welcome the fact that, thanks to the tireless efforts of her tireless colleague Sehnalová, something will finally begin to be done about this problem. As far as I know, it has been drawing attention to the dual quality of products since 2011. I also welcome the Commission's legislative initiative in this regard, which may have finally understood that we are not talking about an excuse, but a real problem. It is certainly right to revise the Unfair Practices Directive, but I am therefore committed to the fact that discriminatory practices against consumers should be inserted as an additional item on the so-called black list of prohibited practices. In this spirit, I have also signed an amendment by My colleague Sehnalová, and I appeal to all colleagues who want to do something for EU consumers to support this proposal. I very much hope that the promises will not remain only on paper, we do not want to have a dual quality of consumers in Europe.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a great deal of research that has shown that there are food products in the European Union's single market and not of the same brand, which at first sight look the same, if we look at packaging and advertising, but which may be of different quality depending on the country in which we buy them. So it may be that products may vary according to the needs and tastes of local consumers, but we demand that if the products are different then the labels and packaging must also be different, because the consumer must not be deceived, but informed with precision and transparency of this diversity. So this path of transparency, as the Commissioner said, can be helped, for example by supporting consumer associations in comparative testing activities, by strengthening the role of the Commission's Joint Research Centre, which can be in support of national market security authorities, and by adding these practices to the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive. These are actions that can make the single market more transparent and close to the consumer.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the studies used to explain the differences in the quality of products within the internal market are insufficient to justify the adoption of this text. We need to be more careful in the conclusions, because the adaptation of products to the market respects mechanisms that are naturally beyond the reach of legislators. I understand the clear desire here to want to once again standardise and centralise control procedures at the Commission level. But the proposed level of control seems disproportionate. The local level seems much better suited in this case. Local or national characteristics must be taken into account, whether in the price formation mechanism, the standards or production standards to be met, such as the requirements of consumers, whether according to their standard of living or even the tastes of the local population. It would be good to put an end to this excessive centralisation within the European Union, not to infantilise consumers and to respect the freedom of producers.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would very much like to support this report. This is not often the case here, but it requires a lot of self-denial. This report should consist of a single sentence: 'with a view to confusing labelling practices on the European market for products of different quality by means of identical or confusingly similar labels, Member States are called upon to adopt rules to prevent this phenomenon'. The end! Ms. Sehnalová, for god's sake, 45 paragraphs over and over again about the same! Reading this is more harmful than all the food additives you are writing about here. It is impossible to get through it: in a circle, the same thing is repeated over and over again. What do we have here at all? Some high-level forum on improving the functioning of the food supply chain. Our Lady! It sounds like the names of communist institutions that I remember from my childhood. It is not possible to write laws in this way, because it is legislative talk. The law should be short, unambiguous and easy to read for everyone. For this reason, I will try to support this report and I am really pleased to note that there is nothing about women in it. This is a very good prognosticator.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Sehnalova, and our shadow rapporteur, Ivan Tefanec, because I believe that if the vote goes in the right direction tomorrow and we manage to avoid automatically including two levels of quality in Article 6 of the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive, we will have achieved something important for the internal market.  It is clear to us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, as Mr Etefanec has pointed out directly, that of course all consumers in Europe, no matter where they come from, have the same rights. And that is what all businesses in this internal market must be able to measure. The Commission was right to indicate this in its proposal. So thank you very much, Commissioner.  However, not all people in Europe have the same taste. Businesses must face up to this challenge, and the European legislator must also face up to this challenge. That is why it is right that we should create transparency. But that is why there will continue to be products in which there is a different fish in Portugal than in Poland. And while clearly both countries started with P, people may have different ideas about how to taste a fish stick. And that is why, in the end, there may be different designs that would have to be taken. That is why transparency is important, so that those involved know what is in it. That is why I hope that, in the end, we will be able to conclude the report in this way, and that it was also adopted in committee. I hope that my fellow Members will be able to agree to this in the end. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "Andreas, I know that in Europe we have different tastes and habits. However, I would like you to make it clear that if the contents of two fish cans or two boxes of washing powder are different, then the packaging must not be confusingly similar? On the package you can not only petitem explain what is inside. The packaging must be different. I would like us to make this very clear.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for this opportunity to pick out another example. It took me a long time to understand that detergents of a certain brand in Germany and France are based on completely different formulations, because in France ammonia traditionally plays a role as a chemical of cleanliness in people's noses and in Germany chlorine. Here, however, in the border area between Germany and France, we have never started the debate about whether the French are better served with ammonia or the Germans with chlorine. I admit, however, that in the situation in which we are currently in Eastern Europe and throughout Europe, such differences in taste naturally have political relevance, and that is why I am quite prepared to say – and I have made this clear – that transparency is important. However, I would not go so far as to ban the points relevant to the internal market, which are of course important for manufacturers in order to be able to distribute a product throughout Europe in the long term. If it is possible to unify the designs in the premises of bathrooms and toilets and if ammonia and chlorine can somehow be brought together, then I would have no problem with that. And I would be reluctant to ban this per se from producers, because, of course, in the end there are costs for the production of these chemicals and the internal market can only have its full effect if they can really choose the cheapest production variants.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Two blue cards were also addressed to Mr. Schwab. It happens, however, that the remaining discussions must end at 11.45 a.m. So, if we were to now give blue cards, once you have also accepted one — there were two more proposals — the debate would never end, which is why I am very sorry to tell you that at the moment there will be no more blue cards, in this case for Mr Schwab, because he has just accepted one and has responded to it.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, there are not four Europes. One you would want in the north, one you would like in the south, one you would like in the west and one you would like in the east. There is a Europe, only one internal market and the same rules must apply to all. There are no second- or first-class Europeans: we are all Europeans and we are entitled to the same protection, especially when it comes to food, and therefore human health. The health of a European is no less valid in the east than in the west, north or south. The existence of disparities between products marketed and distributed in the single market, under the same brand name and with the same packaging is unacceptable. In the face of this scandal, it is imperative that the national authorities of the 28 countries and the European Commission coordinate for better cross-border cooperation and more efficient data sharing on these products. It is fundamental to combat the double level of quality in the European area. I ask you, Commissioner, to measure the seriousness - and I know you are measuring this - of the problem by completing your communication last April and to publish results by the end of this year.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, the infamous fact that the same trademarks are sold with different content in different parts of Europe shows very clearly the attitude of entrepreneurs from some of the Western countries.  Selling a brand of different quality means that you think people in different parts of Europe deserve to consume different things at the same price. And if with fizzy drinks or anything like that there can be a choice whether to buy them or not, when we talk about different quality children's foods, here things are already getting grotesque. They clearly show an unforsa forgotten colonial mentality. They clearly show the division of the European Union into a core and on the periphery and the belief that food and drink of different content can be consumed on the periphery, which quite obviously makes them lower quality.  And the excuse that they're not harmful doesn't work here. It's not about whether they're harmful or not. It is about the fact that someone thinks that people in Eastern and Central Europe deserve to consume poorer quality goods. This hypocrisy must be put to an end!

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: – Mr President, the common European market reduces barriers to traders and facilitates profitability. It brings benefits to consumers, but not when it is abused. Once there are double standards for food and other goods, it needs improvement. How? By improving the legal basis, its strict implementation, more control and higher sanctions targeting unfair commercial practices. The issue of food and the health of European citizens does not tolerate compromises. As a consumer and a citizen of a country affected by the double standard, I insist on ensuring that all European consumers fully enjoy their rights under Union law. A key word in overcoming problems is "responsibility". Responsibility of everyone and everyone in the chain – European Commission, governments, supervisors, manufacturers, traders and consumers.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, it is really important for my countrymen in Lithuania to know that we are equal, not lower-class Europeans, who can be used to produce products of lower quality. I have been the shadow rapporteur for this issue in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and I have put a lot of effort into drawing up quality proposals to curb these scares for producers and traders. These tricks sometimes amount to the simplest deception, the consequences of which are poorer human health, poorer well-being, disappointing expectations. We need to clearly establish common European rules in order to achieve a sustainable and irreversible solution, and our citizens are not considered second-class.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Recently, new, very popular American crisps have entered markets Polish Europe, including the new market. Unfortunately, in Poland, the composition of the newly introduced product was different from that in the western part of the Union, where it did not contain palm oil or monosodium glutamate as we did. However, thanks to mass opposition from consumers, the manufacturer announced a change of composition. Pressure, of course, makes sense.  I am pleased that the consumer response has affected the producer's policy, but it is our right that should provide citizens with adequate protection against unfair practices and should protect all Citizens of the European Union in the same way. This is part of our responsibility.  I will continue to ensure that the same packaging means the same quality and content throughout Europe. Today, we expect further decisive action from the European Commission, and in the pilot project That I have prepared, we have made it clear that the European Parliament will be involved in the work to put an end to these unfair practices. I assure you, Commissioner, we are ready for this.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! I don't have that long, so let me be very direct. It is completely unacceptable in the EU internal market for our consumers to be treated differently, depending on whether they come from Western Europe or Eastern Europe. Now we have ensured that businesses have a single market where they can sell their goods 10 000. And yet there are companies that choose to treat consumers very differently. The same product on the outside, but vastly different qualities on the inside. We're not going to put up with that! I think we should ban this unfair commercial practice in the European Union. We do not have second-class consumers in Europe. However, take and sell some decent products to our consumers all over Europe! I really hope that we will send a clear signal today from the European Parliament, and I really hope that we can unite in this House to ban this totally unacceptable, unfair commercial practice. Consumers in Europe must be the same, they must be treated equally and not at two different levels.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Four years ago, at the start of this period, we were very active with colleagues from Croatia, Poland, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and my Citizens of Latvia complained about this, between Eastern and Western Europe. We used every possible means to convince our Western colleagues that this is a problem. And it must be said that it was only last year, when this problem was also heard by the Commission and Juncker in their speeches, that this work really got an acceleration. This was particularly accelerated when we reached out to the Committee on Budgets for a project to study the methodology for comparing products. This year, too, we have tabled a proposal for research to take place also on non-food products. It is quite clear that discrimination must stop. It is quite clear that the labelling of identical products must be identical and, if the quality of the products is different, there must be a different label. Clearly, these differences that exist are very much determined by the fact that large companies are making more profits at the expense of fooling consumers in Eastern and Central Europe. I very much hope that the Commission will seriously consider our proposals. I am convinced that both legislative changes are needed , both in European legislation and in the supervisory authorities, because otherwise the individual institutions are unlikely to deal with this problem. So, commission, we keep working!

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Mr President, yesterday Jean-Claude Juncker reiterated that Europe must be big on the big issues and small on small issues. However, we, as part of our societies, know that there are topics that only seem small, but actually leave great impressions in our fellow citizens.  Big politics is sometimes only great in the corridors of our institutions. One such small but actually very big topic is the double standards of products in Europe. A drink, cosmetics or chocolate sold with the price and packaging of a familiar brand, but of poor quality, does not undermine the credibility of the brand itself as much as in the European ability to ensure equal treatment for our citizens throughout the Union.  That is why we need to make sure that there are common rules on the quality of goods for all Europeans. We at the ERA also insist on having a common food testing methodology developed by the European Commission's Common Research Centre across Europe. We must not forget that the second quality goods do not create a second quality Europeans, but only a second quality Europe.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, it is not once that greed has led to profits by misleading consumers.
