We have seen this in the financial sector and we are now seeing the same story in trade in global brands, especially in eastern countries. Such practices should be prohibited, as European citizens in Eastern countries must have the same rights as other citizens in the rest of the European Union.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: "Thank you very much for the floor, Mr President. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. The European Union cannot allow anyone under the same brand name to receive a product of lower quality than a fellow citizen purchasing in another Member State! With this report, a clear political and legal guideline is finally being put in place in the fight against dual product quality. I am particularly pleased that my proposals, such as the F-Number or the development of a new EU monitoring and control unit within the Commission's Central Laboratory for Food Safety, or, for example, my other proposal, the amendment of the UCPD, or, thirdly, the prohibition on the sale of products of different quality within the same brand, have been included in the resolution. Thank you very much to rapporteur Sehnalová, Mr Nekov, and the others. An excellent report has been made. Thank you for listening.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to add to what has been said here – with which I agree, except with what Mr Schwab said – that last year, our group, a group of colleagues from the Czech Republic, Croatia, Romania and Italy, I organised a conference – and I want to raise the alarm. The large companies that were present at this debate about dual products have raised some absolutely egotising arguments. They raised the issue of taste – as we have heard here, that each country has a different taste – and raised the issue of purchasing power. Colleagues, I come from the producers' area. If you want a specific taste in a particular country, you put a specific packaging and label. If you take into account the purchasing power, you bring to that country a first quality product with a specific packaging, and another second quality product with another specific packaging. This is about deception and not just the fact that we have second-hand or first-rate citizens. It's a scam, it's unfair competition and, Commissioner, you have to be careful that these big companies are not going to give up, even if we here adopt a regulation. I want the amendment that the rapporteur has tabled and signed over 70 colleagues to be voted on, because we need consumer protection, we need equal treatment, we need to remove this deception and the wrong money for big companies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, products of two qualities in the single market really are gangrene because there is discrimination against consumers, especially in Eastern Europe, and this must be stopped. Mr President, in a short time the Prime Minister of Skopje, Zoran Zaev, will be speaking in the plenary of the European Parliament. This is a fiesta in order to support the despicable agreement of the Prespas signed by Zaev with the Tsipras-Cammenos government. I denounce Zaev's presence in the European Parliament. In my presence, I will not legitimise the libations of Zaev and the despicable agreement of the Prespas. Not in the cave of the name of our Macedonia and our history! Macedonia is one and Greek! I'm leaving in protest.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the report she has presented to us, but above all on her long-standing commitment to highlighting and trying to resolve a serious issue which is of many dimensions and has a significant impact on the lives of European citizens. I find it unacceptable for manufacturers, manufacturers and companies to mislead consumers by presenting dual quality products without allowing them to distinguish their composition and characteristics. In order to avoid being misinformed, every European citizen has the right to distinguish the composition, quality and characteristics of a product, especially when it is a food, whether he buys it in his own country or in another country he visits. For this to happen, the European Union will have to strictly implement existing legislation, protect its citizens and if it has to revise that legislation.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fact that the same packaging should contain the same product of the same quality is what we all understand, and it is surprising that it has taken so many years to persuade the Commission, too, to help enforce this rule. I am glad that a number of initiatives have been launched in the European Parliament and the Commission has heard calls for clearer rules.  We are proud that the Czech Republic has played an important role in this process. And I would like to thank my colleague Olga Sehnalová, who has been very systematically involved in this subject for many years. It was also the Ministry of Agriculture of the Czech Republic that promoted this solution at the level of the Council of Ministers. The methodology prepared by the European Commission can help Member States assess whether a product is breaking the rules, and we should know the first results as soon as possible. Of course, I also expect a positive result in dealing with the directive that we will be discussing. Thank you again to my colleagues for this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I want to tell you that it is absolutely unacceptable to have poorer, worse quality products in Central and Eastern Europe – because that is the problem. – and I am not only referring to such products, such as those for babies, newborns, which is an extremely serious problem and should also be considered by other for a. I am referring – and it has been mentioned here – to banking products, which are much worse and in the disinterest of customers in Central and Eastern Europe, to insurance products, which are different in Western Europe and in Central and Eastern Europe. , and I am referring here to this because we have among us the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Mrs Mogherini. This is a serious situation, because the citizens of Central and Eastern Europe feel discriminated against, and this must stop. This is the case for Romania and Bulgaria with the Schengen area, where we are held instead of 12 years, without being received in this common area, even though we fulfil all the conditions. This is an unacceptable situation, which must stop as soon as possible.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. Chairman, listening to the languages that dominate this chamber this morning, it is evident that a major problem is pressing on the peoples of Central and Eastern Europe. So the problem is clear, discrimination is there for sure.  I can say that Mrs. Šojdrova and I organized an exhibition here in the European Parliament two years ago where we presented products from Croatia, Germany and the Czech Republic. The difference not only was in taste, the difference was also in the composition of the product. In particular, potatoes that are the basic ingredient of chips did not exist in chips sold on the Croatian market. You can see everything from that.  So it is evident that the dual quality of the product affects health and no one can say that a child, a three-month-old baby, can taste one or the other. So it's not about any local and regional tastes or tastes, it's about wanting equality and there's been a lot of talk about wanting Europe, east and west equal, but those were just words. So, enough words, we want to move on and we ask the Commission to finally change this legislation.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, double quality has existed, exists and will exist if we today, in parliament's plenary, do not give a massive vote with extra. And I say this because I am rapporteur in this report and I have had meetings with those involved and we cannot accept explanations such as 'producers rely on the taste perception of consumers' or 'adjust recipes with cheaper ingredients, just to align with the purchasing power of certain citizens'. Commissioner, we were afraid to send you - 'fear', colleagues did not want to send - very concrete amendments, but I ask you, you have this possibility, to set up or give tasks to a directorate, to a service of yours, to audit on the production flow these factories that are suspected of double standard. Only then can we draw strong signals and have coherent action to stop this phenomenon so offensive to all Europe's consumers.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Fairness, equality, these are the basic values that the European Union is betting on. And if these values are to be true, they should be in the case of food, in our most sensitive item, that is, food products and basic food. We are called to draw attention to what is happening, that it is not fair, that it is not fair, that it is criminal in fact, that we can flood eastern European markets, central European markets, with misleading labels or content such as palm oil, and avoid this in the West.  It is therefore right that this report was adopted in order to be adopted. My sincere congratulations to all, the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for a good report.  Together, however, we are now in order, on the basis of the commission's final work, as well as us, and the pressures exerted by consumers to make order in this market, which is the most sensitive.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their remarks and for their unanimous support. I can see that all Members, irrespective of their political group, are ready to support this report. I can only express the Commission’s sincere desire to work with all of you to find a solution that will address the concerns of those among us who have been calling for more action on this issue, while at the same time making sure this does not create any distortions in our Member States and our single market. I believe that we all wish for fairness and equality on the European single market. I hope that together we will achieve these goals as soon as possible: let us, as soon as possible, adopt the report and adopt our proposals and fair trade practices, and see how we can really enforce our instruments for defending consumer rights.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let me thank you warmly for today's debate and for all the words of support. Let me use this last minute of my time to thank my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs in the IMCO committee, as well as the rapporteurs of the opinions on the ENVI and AGRI committees, Bilyana Borzano and Momchil Nekov. I am also glad that it was the Social Democrats in the IMCO committee who initiated the creation of this report. And I believe that our vote today will confirm the readiness of our Parliament, in addition to a number of specific recommendations that are in the report, also to amend the already mentioned Directive on unfair commercial practices. This is an important gesture towards the citizens, that in addition to admitting the problem, there is also a real willingness to solve it.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – On the issue of dual quality, the European Parliament began to take a close interest back in 2011, when a study carried out by the Consumers Association of the Slovak Republic showed that the composition and prices of six branded foods vary considerably between EU countries. In the context of the follow-up to this investigation, the rapporteur first asked the Commission whether, in the Commission's view, this dual quality is a problem relating to the functioning of the single market and consumer protection. I agree with Parliament's position that equal access to high-quality goods in a non-discriminatory manner in the single market should be a real right for all European citizens. If this is not the case, the essential functioning of the single market and consumer confidence in the single market may be seriously undermined. In addition, consumers should be informed in a clear and transparent manner that the product they have purchased or is aware of in another Member State is different in order to avoid confusion between the consumer and his misconception of the product being purchased. It is also important to raise consumer awareness of products, their characteristics and composition. It should be noted that the marketing of products of a purposefully different composition in different parts of the EU, which the consumer can easily consider identical, is unfair practice and should therefore not be acceptable. Parliament's rapporteur therefore considers in this regard that the addition of Annex I to the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive is the most effective way of dealing with all issues relating to manifest dual quality in the European Union.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – When the first news about the dual quality of food emerged a few years ago, i.e. that the Eastern European market offers consumers products of poorer quality than western European citizens, EU officials and leading food manufacturers, they just waved a wave and even made a joke of it. Today, thanks to the reporting woman, we can hold in our hands a report which states that food manufacturers market products of different quality or weight on the EU single market from different ingredients in the same or indistinguishable packaging for consumers. Brand name, packaging design, image in ads are the same at first glance, yet the recipe, ingredients or proportions are different. This is a deliberate misrepresentation of consumers in the hope of greater benefit. Unfortunately, this is usually done at the expense of eastern European consumers. In many cases, manufacturers explained the differences in product components with different local tastes. However, research has shown that the quality of not only food, but also other consumer products such as detergents is poorer. It is difficult to explain why Eastern Europeans want detergents of lower quality?! With regard to clocking, we have seen that the Commission can move very quickly if it wants to. Here's another burning topic that's been waiting for a solution for several years! We look forward to the Commission's legislative action.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that the problem of so-called dual quality products has been noticed by the most important EU institutions. I thank the Rapporteur for the initiative in the form of this report. Given that there is no concrete legislative proposal yet in this area, our vote is particularly important. I believe that the problem should be clarified in detail, not only with regard to food, but also with regard to household goods and cleaning products.  The translations of producers that changes in the composition of their products in different countries are due only to their 'concern for different local tastes and tastes' are naïvy and unconvincing. The producers do not present how they examined the alleged taste preferences of Czechs, Slovaks, Croats or Poles; have not shown according to which data one consumer group expects a lower fish content in fish sticks and more palm oil in butter. We welcome the desire to develop appropriate methodologies for proceedings before consumer authorities in individual countries in order to apply tools that are to be used at local level. At the next stage, it is also important to emphasise the role of the EC, but its role must be properly balanced.  In conclusion, I support the text of the report because, in its current form, it proposes an appropriate emphasis on producers, but without too far-reaching projects harmonising legislation in this area at EU level.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for a Resolution on Uganda, the arrest of opposition MPs (2018/2840(RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, it’s unclear exactly what happened on 13 August this year in a northwest province of Uganda during political campaigning for a by—election. President Museveni’s vehicle was indeed attacked but lethal force was used against protesters. Opposition politicians such as Robert Kyagulanyi were detained and allegedly even tortured. But this lack of clarity over the facts does not mask the definite increase in concern expressed over increased repression of the political opposition in Uganda. The deterioration of the fundamental freedoms of expression, assembly and association in Uganda is indeed worrying, as are President Museveni’s efforts now to entrench his power by changing the law to allow a president to hold office over the age of 75. Over the next three years before the elections in 2021, the international community must watch closely and call on the Museveni Government to investigate all human rights abuses, to uphold the rule of law and freedom of speech, and to fight hard to prevent election fraud and corruption.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Do we really want to become a partner for crime? Because that is what we will be if we remain silent here. If, when journalists are behind bars, beatings and torture in detention, in other words human rights violations, are the order of the day, then we Greens cannot accept that. This must be stopped! We Greens stand alongside Bobi Wine. Bobi Wine is not only an opposition leader, he is a figurehead for young people, he teaches them peace and democracy, he promotes human rights, and his voice must not be silenced. We call for the release of the prisoners. We are calling for an investigation into the incidents and criminal proceedings against the perpetrators, including the police. In development cooperation with Uganda, we must support the country's own human rights commission in such a way that it does not remain a toothless tiger. We have the opportunity to exert pressure here and we have to exert pressure here.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while Uganda is showing itself to the world as a welcoming country to refugees, as it currently hosts 1.4 million, we cannot close our eyes to events that undermine freedom and human and civil rights.  Surely the law removing the maximum age limit at 75 for presidential elections is now moving several groups to demonstrate against President Museveni, who took office in 1986 and is once again eligible for election in 2021 despite his age. Municipal elections in Arua have led to further disagreements in the country and violence that has spread throughout Uganda. Ugandan police and army have been at the centre of clashes during demonstrations and political debates. The arrest of members of parliament belonging to the opposition, as in the case of Bobi Wine, and a high rate of deaths and injuries, cannot be overlooked. Once again, we are committed to emphasising that freedom of expression and fundamental rights cannot be silenced by violence. All my best wishes for a good recovery at Bobi Wine.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Author. – Mr President, on 13 August this year Ugandan police and army arrested and beaten four members of Parliament's opposition, at least two journalists and twenty-nine other people before the local elections. Opposition politicians and the defendants' lawyer have said the detainees were tortured during their arrest. These facts again underline violations of freedom of association, assembly and expression particularly serious in Uganda. However, President Museveni, in power since 86 and accused of electoral fraud, continues with significant Western support.  We used to support him for his role in the fight against jihadist terrorism and now we support him above all for his support in achieving our migration policy objectives. Or, put another way: Uganda does the dirty work for us, serving as a stopper for migrants from Somalia and Congo who want to seek a better life by fleeing misery and war; that's why he's our partner. Enough of the inconsistency. The European Union must condemn the Afghan authoritarian regime and side with human rights and fundamental freedoms at once.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Uganda is an important country for stability in Central and East Africa. Uganda is involved in peace-building operations in conflict regions. Uganda has taken in many refugees from South Sudan and the DRC, and it is an important partner for the EU.  This makes us all the more concerned about the political situation in the country. President Museveni has ruled with a hard hand since 1986. It was only in the spring that he had the Constitution amended in order to remain in office without age restrictions, even after the next elections. But dissatisfaction is growing, especially among the young population – three-quarters of Uganda's population is under thirty years of age. And with the entry of popular artist Bobi Wine into politics on the opposition side, there is a serious opponent to Museveni. Opposition candidates have already won by-elections in some constituencies.  How nervous the Museveni regime is in the run-up to the elections in two years' time was demonstrated by the events in August, where, after a campaign event, bobi Wine's driver was shot dead, Bobi Wine himself was imprisoned for treason, and several of his party-goers and journalists were jailed. The events of August need to be clarified. We should strongly support democratic development.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, the arrests of Ugandan opposition politicians, as well as serious human rights violations such as extra-judicial killings and the excessive use of force, were reason for the UN High Commissioner to call for an independent investigation and to ask for the perpetrators to be brought to justice – and this House today echoes that call. We also urge respect for the independence of parliamentarians: that is vital for the future of Uganda, as is respect for freedom of expression and for the role of independent media. All our EU programmes are conditional upon respect for human rights and I think we should not hesitate to use that leverage, including in respect of Uganda, in order to stand for our principles and to the stand with the people in Uganda – who are worried, as is the Human Rights Commission there.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, let me first of all welcome the high representative's presence in our debate. I would add that the initiative of our discussion on Uganda comes from our political group, because we felt that as parliamentarians we cannot remain indifferent when elected officials are arrested in such troubling conditions.  The freedom to exercise freely and the independence of parliament are essential elements in a democratic society. Unfortunately, this is not the case in Uganda, where opposition representatives have been intimidated. The arrest of Bobi Wine and the three other parliamentarians is the most recent example of this. I believe that these actions must be condemned in the strongest terms and that the charges against them should be dropped. Through our development cooperation with Uganda, I believe we have an effective means of lobbying to try to improve the human rights situation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Museveni has for many years been carrying out acts of repression against the opposition. My peers and friends, political activists, young Ugandan democrats – I am thinking of Brenda Nabukenya, Sam Muyizzi, many other activists – have been detained and tortured in recent years. Today, with the shocking story of Bobi Wine, the systematic detention of journalists and the murder of Yasin Kawuma, we see a further deterioration, a further degradation of the democratic and constitutional state.  I believe that we need to act today. We have European programmes, and I am thinking more specifically of development cooperation linked to budgetary assistance, which must really be conditional on respect for human rights. We cannot accept that Europe should be indirectly complicit in increasing abuses of the population and of the democratic world in Uganda.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rights to demonstration and free association are universal prerogatives that under undersoe all democracies.  In Uganda, they do not seem to take the same view, especially when we are witnessing a protest leading to shootings, beatings, murders, torture and the arrest of six Members of Parliament and thirty other people. The balance sheet of this protest is more reminiscent of a scenario of war than that of a democracy, in a country where repression and arrests of politicians and opponents are not the exception but the rule. Ladies and gentlemen, the problem lies at its root: we are faced with a President and a government that violate parliament's prerogatives and its independence, and this goes far beyond violations of human and civil rights, this represents the end of the rule of law. The removal of Ugandan laws that violate the rights to freedom of expression and association, such as the Criminal Defamation Act, is the first step uganda must take. I therefore call on this Parliament to use the political influence provided by development aid programmes, in particular budget support programmes, to strengthen the defence and promotion of human and civil rights in Uganda.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the trial procedure, in the context of military courts, of several Ugandan opponents, raises an essential question relating to the rule of law. It would be more acceptable, in our view, if they had committed an offence, they would be brought before a civil court. Similarly, opposition MPs were arrested and even tortured during the election campaign. These outrageous acts are unacceptable. But is the European Parliament really in a position, at this moment, to give lessons in the rule of law, when Hungary, whose sovereign people have wrested their freedom through immense sacrifices from communist totalitarianism, has been the victim, this week, right here in our walls, of a real attack on its sovereignty? When Poland is singled out by the leaders of Brussels, who do not derive their legitimacy from nowhere, except from cenacles close to Soros et al? When the peoples of Austria, Italy, the Czech Republic, the Slovak peoples are indicted when they have just very clearly appointed their leaders in the most democratic way possible? So let's talk about Uganda, but let's start by respecting the only democracy that is worthwhile, that based on the suffrage of the peoples in European countries and respect for their sovereignty.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, the governments of many countries apply procedures to opposition leaders that violate fundamental human rights. These countries include Uganda. Unfortunately, this is an almost standard set of steps where opposition leaders are intimidated by the murders of their associates. Falsely accused, e.g. of possessing weapons, are unlawfully held in custody and tortured in custody, and subsequently charged with treason for merely criticizing government officials. Press representatives are locked up after the rally. At the end of the meeting, which they attended as representatives of the press. That is why we must also strongly say to Uganda that we will not tolerate violations of fundamental human rights. If the Ugandan government's approach does not change, the EU must provide only direct assistance to those fighting in Uganda for respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, following the results of the municipal elections in Arua, several opponents have been arrested and tortured, including the popular musician and now elected Mr Bobi Wine, known as the President of the Ghetto. This wave of arrests led to nationwide protests, which were violently suppressed by security agents, whose brutal actions remain unpunished and which are urgently required to investigate. Today, once again, we are debating the situation of fundamental freedoms in Uganda, whose regime persists in allowing atrocities against its people, namely the murder of children in the name of rituals and the persecution of disabled people and homosexuals. Ms Mogherini, the European Union must clearly condemn the intensification of repression in Uganda and demand the immediate release of all imprisoned opponents and, taking advantage of its capacity as a donor to development aid programmes, increase pressure on President Yoweri Museveni's regime to honor its commitments under international law with regard to freedom of expression , association and assembly and respect the principles of the rule of law, democracy and respect for human rights.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Mogherini, yesterday President Juncker underlined in the debate on the State of the Union the importance of Africa as a priority of European foreign policy. We share it. But not at the cost of degrading our commitment to the rule of law and democratic quality.  Uganda has been appreciated by the European Union for its cooperation on migration, but it cannot be at the cost of looking the other way when authoritarian drift has led to reform of the Constitution and laws to allow the indefinite re-election of Museveni — who has been in power for thirty-two years, competing with Paul Biya in Cameroon and the Obiang Theodore in Guinea. , and certainly not to look the other way, when opposition deputies are arrested, as well as journalists and activists critical of growing authoritarianism in Uganda, including Bobi Wine, a musician who is also a deputy and who was tortured and arrested after his release, as he tried to move to the United States to deal with kidney ailments resulting from his torture.  The European Union has an obligation to send a clear message, particularly in a country that still criminalizes sexual orientation, Uganda.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, aontaím le mo chomhghleacaithe Preda, Zeller agus Svoboda maidir leis an tuarascáil seo. Ní féidir linn cur suas le cad atá ag tarlú in Uganda. Níl aon saoirse ann. Tá deachtóir ann. Tá sé ann le blianta fada. Ní theastaíonn uaidh go mbeadh aon lucht freasúra ann. Má théann siad ina choinne, cuirtear i bpríosún iad agus an rud céanna leis an bpreas agus na meáin. Agus dá bhrí sin, mar a dúirt mo chara Svoboda, caithfimid féachaint ar an gcabhair a thugaimid dóibh. In a lán tíortha, táimid ag tabhairt airgid ar chúiseanna maithe, ach níl sé á úsáid mar ba chóir é a úsáid. Dá bhrí sin, tá sé an-tábhachtach go bhféachaimis air sin agus b’fhéidir go dtarraingeoimis siar beagáinín ón gcabhair a thugaimid dóibh go dtí go dtugann siad isteach rúin agus moltaí níos fearr.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I share the opinion that it is vital for Ugandan democracy to ensure the independence of the country’s Parliament as an institution and the independence of its members in pursuing their role as elected representatives. Moreover, I support the call to launch a prompt, independent, impartial and effective investigation into the killing of Mr Yasiin Kawuma and into reports of deaths and of the excessive use of force during protests. The authorities should guarantee, protect and promote fundamental rights, including the civil and political rights of Uganda’s citizens, such as freedom of speech and freedom of assembly. I would also like to take the opportunity, in this Chamber, to praise you, High Representative, for your hard work and your smart work aimed at enhancing the influence of the European Union and making it more visible in international affairs.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start with something that doesn’t relate directly to the issue that we are discussing today: we meet every month to discuss human rights violations and take action. I think that it is important for me to say a few words on the system that we have built together to assess human rights violations and ensure accountability, and bring perpetrators to justice. Today the existence of the International Criminal Court is being questioned. And I think it important to say formally and clearly in this Chamber that it is not being questioned by the European Union and that we will continue to strongly and fully support the ICC and its work. I know that this is the strong position of this Parliament, and of all our Member States. We remember very well when, 20 years ago in Rome, the Statute of the ICC was finally ratified. We remember very well that, after Rwanda and the war in the Balkans, the world needed real change and we all know that the International Criminal Court has brought that change. It has strengthened universal justice beyond power politics and beyond geopolitical interests. It has made it clear that justice is not an enemy of reconciliation, but, on the contrary, the basis for reconciliation, for it is when the victims feel powerless, when crimes are met with impunity, that reconciliation is much harder to achieve. Accountability is essential to build the foundations for peace. So the court may not be perfect, but the best way forward for us is not to dismantle our global institutions. The way forward for us is to make them stronger and to build a strong, more effective multilateral system. That is why, once again – I want to say so very clearly and very strongly in this room – that is why the European Union will continue to be a strong supporter of the ICC, and I am counting on your support in the work that lies ahead of us. Coming to the issue that we are discussing in this item of the agenda, on 13 August, as most of you have mentioned, at least 35 people were arrested in the Arua District in the north—west of Uganda immediately before a local by—election. Among the people arrested were four Members of Parliament belonging to the opposition, and in the following days various Ugandan sources reported that security forces had inflicted brutal treatment on the detainees, including the Members of Parliament. The European Union delegation and Member Statesʼ ambassadors on the ground followed the situation extremely closely and issued a joint statement on 17 August, calling upon all forces in Uganda to respect the rule of law and individual rights. We got the authorisation from the military authorities. Our delegation and European ambassadors were able to visit two of the Members of Parliament, Bobi Wine in the military barracks where he was being detained and Francis Zaake in the hospital where he was undergoing treatment. Both of them had several wounds and needed extensive medical treatment. They were eventually authorised to leave the country at the beginning of September. However, they are still facing treason charges. An investigation into the alleged abuses has been launched by the police. The Speaker of Parliament decided to set up an another committee to deal with this issue. Finally, a report is also expected from the Ugandan Human Rights Commission. We will wait for the conclusions of these investigations, but let me state very clearly once again that security forces have a duty to respect everyone’s freedom to peacefully demonstrate in support of their opinions. The allegations of torture are serious. If they are confirmed, perpetrators must be prosecuted and victims must obtain redress. Uganda has, unfortunately, a long history of violence and conflict, and we know very well that its people deserve some peace and the right to peacefully express their opinion. We’ve made this position very clear to the Ugandan Government and we will continue to engage with it so that responsibilities can be established and perpetrators are brought to justice.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Human rights, the source of which is the inalienable and indisputable dignity of man, should be guaranteed and respected by each state. That is why the case of an independent member of Parliament in Uganda, Robert Kyagulanyi Ssentamu, also known as Bobi Wine, is a worrying manifestation of violations of fundamental human rights, especially those described as absolute, which cannot be restricted in any case. The authorities of each State should be a guarantor of respect for rights and freedoms, not only by complying with the provisions of international conventions, but also by ensuring the protection of human rights. Moreover, it is the moral duty of state authorities to respect human dignity and to protect the individual from abuse of power. The Ugandan authorities, like every other country in the world, should respect and protect human rights. All political prisoners should be released and the practice of eliminating opposition representatives and their sympathizers from public life should be discontinued and uganda's armed forces should be stopped in the fight against local opposition.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Myanmar/Burma, in particular on journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo (2018/2841(RSP)).

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Burmese journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo have dared to investigate the murder of ten Rohingyas in the village of Inn Din in their country. These crimes took place in the course of the military offensive in which hundreds of thousands of Rohingyas were murdered or displaced. They have been condemned because the military and the government are doing everything they can to keep the horrific crimes against the Rohingya undocumented and unpunished. We call for their release immediately and without conditions. The UN Commission of Inquiry impressively documents that the Myanmar military may also be responsible for crimes against humanity and war crimes in its country and against the Rohingya. They explicitly named the military chief Min Aung Hlaing and five other officers. When the report is discussed in the UN Human Rights Council next week, the EU must clearly and unequivocally call for the prosecution of the responsible military by the International Criminal Court or an ad hoc court and, if necessary, also adapt its own targeted sanctions.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: author. – Mr President, for some time now my delegation has been very hesitant to call for the trade relationship we have with Myanmar to be reviewed. But today, following this latest development, we find ourselves in a situation where we can no longer simply say that Myanmar is a country that deserves the trade access we provide to it. There needs to be a fundamental review of that relationship. Furthermore, the United Nations today has provided us with a report which is very clear in its findings. As part of the international community and as a set of institutions, Europe must ensure that it provides its support to the international community. So, at United Nations level, we must do the right thing and ensure that the voices we have at the table there are not allowing Myanmar to go unchecked. Our voices must be the loudest at that table. (Applause)

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, we will not and cannot allow ourselves to stand by while crimes against humanity and genocide have been happening in Myanmar. The Rohingya people are victims of ethnic cleansing. They are being punished, killed, raped and displaced from their homes. They are suffering and dying in refugee camps like Cox’s Bazar in Bangladesh. Journalists have been persecuted simply for reporting on the atrocities committed against Rohingya people. The Myanmar military and the Government led by Aung San Suu Kyi have to be held accountable. We call for justice for the Rohingya people and for all those who stand up for their rights and investigate and report on these crimes against humanity. We demand the immediate release of the two Reuter journalists. There are reasons for us to consider whether we should continue to give economic support to the Myanmar regime.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, the decision to jail Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, two Reuter reporters, while they were investigating the massacre of Rohingya is unacceptable. The military regime wanted to send a severe warning to whoever dares to look into military abuses: a real example of censorship through fear for anyone who fights to uncover uncomfortable truths and expose wrongdoing by those in power, and whoever tries to report inconvenient truths. Investigative journalism is the link between the truth and us, and that is precisely why it is vital for democracy. That is why we will always stand up and fight for freedom of thought for journalists, activists and lawyers who express critical views. We must adopt targeted individual sanctions against the leaders of the military regime so long as Myanmar legislation is not aligned with basic international human rights law and standards. We urge the Myanmar authorities to free the two journalists immediately and to repeal the Official Secrets Act and all the other laws that allow the authorities to arrest or harass whoever fights to inform people about the atrocities they are perpetrating.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Mr President, here we are once again talking about the violation of human rights in Myanmar. It should be remembered that August 23rd was the anniversary of the beginning of the Rohingya genocide. An opportunity to remember our failure to hold those responsible accountable.  To remember, too, that expulsion continues and also responds, above all, to large businesses that no one talks about. Military bases are being built on the expoliated lands and the mass entry of transnational capital is being allowed by promoting extractivism, agribusiness and land grabbing that are behind the expulsion of the Rohingya. If, after a genocide, so far confirmed even by the United Nations, the human rights clause included in our trade agreements does not apply, when then will it be time to implement it? When we don't have economic interests? If we do not take strong action to ensure an end to violence, access to justice and non-repetition measures, we will be indirect accomplices to these crimes.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Údar. – A Uachtaráin, a Choimisinéir Mogherini, fáiltím roimh an tuarascáil seo agus go háirithe aontaím leis, gur cheart an bheirt iriseoirí Wa Lone agus Kyaw Soe Oo a ligean saor.  Ní dhearna siad aon rud mídhleathach; ní dhearna siad ach scríobh faoi choireanna uafásacha i gcoinne cearta daonna a rinne fórsaí míleata Mhaenmar. Ní féidir cur suas leis seo. Agus dar le tuarascáil idirnáisiúnta, tá rudaí imithe ar gcúl go mór i Maenmar maidir le saoirse agus go háirithe maidir le muintir Róihinse.  Ceaptar gur cuireadh ar a laghad 10 000 díobh chun báis. Tá 700 000 duine tar éis an tír a fhágáil agus leathmhíle díobh siúd ina leanaí. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid rud éigin a dhéanamh agus caithfimid féachaint go háirithe ar an ngaol trádála atá againn leo – go háirithe an gaol trádála ‘Gach Ní Seachas Airm’ – go dtí ar a laghad go gcuireann siad ar ceal an dlí uafásach sin, an tAcht um Rúin Oifigiúla.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Mr President, the conviction of the two journalists reporting human rights violations by the Myanmar forces is a clear example of the undermining of press freedom. The journalists must be freed at once. As regards the Rohingyas, the situation has not improved. The UN fact-finding mission recently concluded that the Myanmar authorities had committed the most serious human rights violations and the gravest crimes under international law, including genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. The EU and the international community must spare no effort to make the Myanmar authorities stop these atrocities and to ensure that those responsible will be brought to justice. The EU must therefore use all the tools it has, including a review of the trade preferences that Myanmar benefits from under the ‘Everything But Arms’ scheme. The EU needs to take the lead in the UN Security Council on referring the situation to the International Criminal Court, and the UN Security Council must impose a global, comprehensive arms embargo on Myanmar, as well as adopting targeted individual sanctions against those responsible for these heinous crimes.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, High Representative, other Members have already outlined the case of Myanmar journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who were sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment on 3 September for investigating and reporting on human rights violations in Rakhine State. Wa Lone had been writing in-depth stories on sensitive subjects including land grabs by the powerful military and the murder of prominent politician Ko Ni. It’s appalling that he’s not even able to see his new-born daughter. Kyaw Soe Oo worked on an investigative story about Myanmar’s plan to harvest the crops of Rohingya farmers who fled to Bangladesh. He also reported how some Buddhists were enforcing local-level segregation in central Rakhine. And it was only because of these brave journalists that the world got to know about the severe injustices and violations of human rights. Collecting information, High Representative, is not a crime, therefore I am deeply disappointed by Aung San Suu Kyi, who has defended the court’s decision to jail Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo. With this resolution, Parliament is not just urging the authorities in Myanmar to release immediately and unconditionally the two journalists, but also urging the High Representative and the Commission to ensure that wherever we have harassment of journalists we take action in terms of our trade agreements, and that we take action in this case. I think it’s important that in Myanmar we actually have a review of the archaic laws that facilitate these attacks. I hope, High Representative, that you will join us in this call: we do need to act now.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, from debate to debate, we have the impression that the situation in Myanmar is deteriorating. Now it is journalists who are persecuted, convicted, imprisoned for reporting on what is happening there, witnessing the end-of-the-art cruelty of the Burmese government and continuing to witness the ethnic cleansing of the Rohingya, which the UN says is genocide. That is why we are again demanding sanctions and an urgent international investigation. We also call on the UN Security Council to bring those responsible to international justice. There would be nothing worse than getting used to the horror. And I am afraid, sometimes, that our eyes will get used to the horrors that have been committed in Burma for too many years.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, one year on the Myanmar Government has failed to take any credible steps to investigate the crimes against Rohingya and hold those with blood on their hands to account. Instead they are focused on targeting two brave journalists who dare to expose the military’s atrocities. I welcome the ICC ruling that it has jurisdiction over Myanmar’s deportation of the Rohingya population to Bangladesh. It is a crucial step towards ending impunity. However Myanmar’s military leaders have been accused of acting with genocidal intent. Therefore a referral to the ICC for the full scope of human rights violations is Rohingya’s main hope for justice. The international community may take responsibility, must take responsibility, and I ask you, Madam High Representative, to take the lead. Failing to do so sends the signal that Myanmar can continue to commit these atrocities against the Rohingya and other ethnic minorities in northern Myanmar. The longer we wait, the more time Myanmar officials have to destroy evidence in Rakhine State. We must take a united stand now.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to share this point with you today, because the case of the two journalists seems to me to be further evidence that the process of democratic transition is struggling to make its way in that country, and perhaps it should impose on us all the need to review the approach in our policies. Last week, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet, described the results of the international fact-calling mission as shocking during a speech in Geneva. I was also a member of the European Parliament delegation to Myanmar last February, and it is sad to see that almost nothing has changed in months. Now, it is quite clear that the European Union cannot stand by and watch. We are calling not only for the release of the two journalists, but also for all the instruments at our disposal to be used to try to change the course of things in that country.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Mogherini, I had the honour of taking part in the European Parliament observer mission during the last elections in Myanmar. We were impressed by the participation of the people, by the organisation, especially of women, on that day of democracy and that beginning of the transition to freedom after the victory of leader San Suu Kyi. We knew that the Constitution would lag behind, the weight of the armed forces important and binding. And we also knew of forms of extremist, violent and xenophobic Buddhism, and that even then it was not held back by the victorious leader. But what has happened since then in Burma to the Rohingya people goes beyond any more pessimistic forecast: ethnic extermination, genocide, a succession of widely documented violence. Independent journalists arrested, murderers unpunished, media fomenting hatred. We have to say enough is enough. Mr President, I should like to say that we are not in a state of agreement on this. Panzeri to say that this is enough is not just a specific measure, but that we need to change a general line.  Burma is poised: if it does not move, it will once again be an example of shame in the eyes of all the democrats in the world.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, Reuters journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who were investigating the murder of ten Rohingya Muslim men and children discovered in a mass grave in the village of Inn Din in Rakhine State were arrested in December last year and now sentenced to seven years in prison, accused of violating myanmar's archaic official secrets law. Ladies and gentlemen, the only offence of these two courageous journalists - named in the category of international journalists of the year by One World Media - was to do their job, investigate the atrocities committed after the Burmese army offensive in Inn Din in August 2017, which led to the flight of 700,000 people to Bangladesh, and to denounce the war crimes committed in the name of an unacceptable ethical cleansing. Madam High Representative, I would like to congratulate you on your difficult work in relation to certainly one of your biggest headaches which is precisely the dossier on Myanmar, but the truth is that we are constantly presenting resolutions on this country in this Parliament. It is now up to us, representatives of the European people, to say that we are on the side of those who defend a free and independent press and those who condemn the manipulation of justice, the crimes against humanity and the impunity of those who practice them.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I strongly support the calls upon the Government of Myanmar and the security forces to put an end immediately to the ongoing violations against the Rohingya people and other ethnic minorities in northern Myanmar and to ensure that security and the rule of law prevail. The international community must adopt a united and strong stand on this situation. The European Union and the Member States have to take the lead in the UN General Assembly and the upcoming 39th session of the United Nations Human Rights Council and step up their efforts towards the establishment of an international mechanism to back investigations into alleged atrocity crimes and to seek justice by prosecuting those responsible for atrocity crimes. Finally, as is emphasised in this resolution, thousands of Rohingya people, many of whom are children, are internally displaced and in urgent need of humanitarian assistance and protection. Against this background it is paramount to continue to call for immediate and unhindered access throughout the country for the delivery of humanitarian aid.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, a few days ago a Myanmar court sentenced two Reuters journalists to seven years in prison. At the time of their arrest they were working on an investigation into the killing of ten Rohingya men in a village in Rakhine State. We have been following this case very closely from the beginning, almost one year ago. Following their arrest on 18 December last year we requested their immediate release. Our delegation to Myanmar has observed all relevant court hearings, and, together with Member States, we continuously raise the issue with the Myanmar Government. When the court decided to press charges against the two journalists last year on 7 July we again reacted publicly. Many observers saw this trial as a test of media freedom, democracy and the rule of law. It is pretty clear that the test was failed, and we made this clear in our statements released right after the sentence, which will also intimidate other journalists, who could fear undue arrest or prosecution for doing their job.  Throughout the years, we’ve always accompanied Myanmar on its path towards democracy and I still have hope that Myanmar can go back to that path and become an inclusive and free country for all its citizens.  So we ask once again that the prison sentences be reviewed and that the two journalists be released immediately and unconditionally.  The report that they were working on, published almost a year ago, shed light on what was happening in Rakhine State. It contains the same kind of stories, exactly the same kind of stories, that I heard myself from Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh. Those stories have also led to the preliminary report from the United Nations fact-finding mission. The UN report confirms the need for pressure and engagement to make the situation change as soon as possible, and this is exactly what we’ve been doing so far as the European Union. As you know, we were one of the strongest voices calling for a fact-finding mission in 2017 and we are now sponsoring a resolution at the ongoing session of the Human Rights Council to support the recommendations and conclusions of the fact-finding mission. So, for those of you who asked us to do that, we are currently doing it.  The resolution will aim in particular to establish an international accountability mechanism. I discussed the issue with all my interlocutors at the ASEAN regional forum last month in Singapore, in particular with Bangladesh and also with China and Indonesia. We will also discuss the situation when we meet at the upcoming Asia-Europe meeting that we will host next month in Brussels, and of course I will use the UN General Assembly Ministerial Week 10 days from now to discuss how to improve the situation with all the relevant interlocutors, not only in the region, but also in the UN system. There are some urgent measures to be taken. First and foremost guaranteeing full and immediate humanitarian access inside Rakhine State. We are already among the largest humanitarian donors for Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh, but it is vital that aid reaches those in need inside Myanmar. To address these kinds of issues, as well as to improve the overall human rights situation and address the lack of accountability for those who have committed crimes, we are putting pressure on relevant individuals and institutions in Myanmar. We have put in place restrictive measures against seven senior army and police officers associated with serious human rights violations in Rakhine State. In light of the UN report we are considering strengthening these restrictive measures.  We’ve also made it clear to the Myanmar authorities that our trade preferences with Myanmar are linked to clear conditions on human rights and democracy and that to preserve our current trade arrangements we need to see decisive action to improve the situation.  Finally, we’re working closely with the civilian Government of Myanmar to address the root causes of conflict in accordance with the Annan report. The people of Myanmar have asked to turn the page, to go towards a democratic system and country, and they deserve better than this. They deserve a country where journalists are free to do their job and keep the state institutions accountable for their actions and they deserve a country where all citizens, all of them, have the same rights, whatever their faith or the background.  So we will continue to put pressure and to engage so that the country can advance again on its path towards democracy. Thank you very much, and especially I would like to thank all of you who are engaging strongly and closely with the country: parliamentary diplomacy – as always, but especially in this case – is key.  (Applause)

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – More than 650,000 Rohingya Muslims left Rakhine State in Myanmar because of military intervention against this ethnic group. Thousands of homes have been burned, and international organisations are working to deal with this unprecedented humanitarian crisis. We are witnessing one of the most criminal campaigns in the recent history of mankind directed against representatives of a minority. For all this disastrous situation, the myanmar government blames Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army (ARSA). But according to media in the region, Rohingya fleeing to neighbouring countries say that behind these criminal attacks is, in fact, the army of Myanmar that was ordered to force them to flee the country. Ms Aung San Suu Kyi, winner of the Sakharov Prize and the Nobel Peace Prize, is currently the first state councillor in Myanmar. As a member of the government holding these distinctions, it has an obligation to persuade its government to take urgent measures to defend this long-held minority. The way the Buddhist majority treats the approximately 1.1 million Rohingya is unacceptable. I call on myanmar's military and security forces to immediately stop killing and harassing the Rohingya people and to grant immediate access to humanitarian aid organisations.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Cambodia, in particular the Case of Kema Sokha (2018/2842(RSP)).

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. Mr President, allow me first to welcome the Cambodian delegation with opposition leader Sam Rainsy, who is following this debate from the gallery. Welcome, friends! If you want to know the character of a human being, you have to give him power. Abraham Lincoln knew that a long time ago. We met Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen. The world's longest-reigning prime minister is so power-hungry that he uses all the means to stay on for another 10 years. To that end, he ruthlessly pushes aside anyone who stands in the way, as Kem Sokha, former leader of the main opposition party, CNRP, is under pressure in the run-up to the election. Autocrats will not tolerate contradiction. Democracy has been squeezed to death. The Hun Sen government lacks any legitimacy and all the international criticism of it has still failed.  A Flemish proverb says: If you don't want to hear, you have to feel it. It is time for this regime to feel that it is mean. It is therefore high time for sanctions, visa sanctions, trade sanctions. I see no reason to wait any longer.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you to you, Mrs Mogherini, for your statement, which was generally very supportive of the International Criminal Court.  On Cambodia, the elections in Cambodia were neither free nor fair and, as a result, have made the country an autocratic one-party state. The price was high: the largest opposition party in the country was virtually eliminated, independent journalists and human rights defenders intimidated and imprisoned. We demand that the government immediately drop the charges against opposition leader Kem Sokha and other opposition politicians, reverse the dissolution of the CNRP and seek dialogue with the opposition.  We also call on the government to stop the persecution and crackdown on human rights defenders and organisations. It is also necessary to extend the agreement with the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, which expires in December.  There are countless unresolved land conflicts in Cambodia, and it is to be welcomed that the government has now compensated some families for lost land. However, these compensations are not systematic and impunity for expropriation is still widespread. In particular, the EU should press for a review of the 2015 requirements, in particular sugar licences, related to land rights conflicts.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Cambodia's recent history is marked by incredible crimes. The Khmer Rouge have murdered millions of people, and the shadows of that past are still omnipresent. For a long time, it seemed that the country could return to democratic normality. Due to rapid economic development, more and more people began to engage in politics, and these changes have unsettled the Hun Sen regime. In recent years, there has been an increasingly rigorous crackdown on NGOs and opposition politicians. They were arrested on flimsy charges and had to go into exile. I am very pleased that some of them can follow our debate today. It was right that the EU did not allow itself to be misused to legitimise the fake elections and refused to take part in the election observation. That was a crystal clear sign. Europe must now set additional activities – uncompromisingly, quickly and with deadlines. In the economic field, there are many possibilities, as our resolution shows. We owe that to the people of this troubled country.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, the general elections last July, as we feared, saw the majority party win all the seats. That is to say the state of the regression of freedoms in this country, its de facto transformation into a one-party system, the suppression of press freedom, the imprisonment of political opponents and the dissolution of the main opposition party. The release of Kem Sokha, who has been imprisoned for a year, is therefore good news, even though his release remains very conditional, his freedom remains very limited and the number of those still in prison, subject to restrictions of liberty and intimidation, is still as important. However, I would like to stress the situation of trade unionists and those fighting land grabbing, which goes beyond all limits in this country, mainly to the benefit of the sugar industry, including the European one. Thousands of people are being ruined and/or displaced for the greater benefit of the country's leaders. We must not be silent on that either. Human rights are indivisible and I would like, Madam High Representative, to have your views on this particular point.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, I am glad that we have managed to negotiate a very good compromise. However, we have already adopted a similar resolution in September 2017, December 2017, and what are the results? Zero. Ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Cambodia has not changed at all. On the contrary, the crisis that is currently there is escalating even further. I am glad that we have finally come to a much more restrictive and powerful text. We call on the Commission to infer the consequences of what is currently happening in Cambodia, to establish a list of those responsible who will be sanctioned in the form of visa bans in the EU, in order to give a clear signal to the Member States to start doing something about the situation. It is unacceptable that we really accept one declaration after another, and the situation has become worse and worse, so we need to work together – all the EU components – the Commission, the High Representative for Foreign Policy and Security – and force the Government of Cambodia to cooperate. The European Union must use all its instruments to help address the situation in Cambodia at present.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, first of all I want to welcome Sam Rainsy and his delegation into this hall and I appreciate their uncompromising fight for the democratic future of Cambodia. Those people really deserve all kinds of support, from us and from the free world in general. Despite the recent releases of a few political prisoners, including Kem Sokha, the situation in Cambodia is deteriorating further. Elections in July were nothing but a farce. All the seats went to the ruling party. What do they say about this? They appreciate it, they like it, they call it ‘elections’. There cannot be another scenario from our side: we must firmly demand that the Cambodian Government give back the voice and the rights of its people. We must put an end to impunity. To achieve this, the European Union has to finally move from statements to actions. Cambodia cannot benefit any longer from GSP Plus trade preferences. Those responsible, Mr President, must be identified and punished by banning them from travelling to Europe and by freezing their assets.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, although the 23—year—long rule of the Cambodian People’s Party (CPP) has led to significant economic development in Cambodia, recent trends in the country’s political development are extremely worrying. The entrenchment of the CPP’s political dominance over the past few years has led to serious concerns for democracy. The last elections are very instructive in this regard, being widely considered by foreign observers as an undemocratic charade. And there are plenty of other concerns, too: the arrest and detention of Kem Sokha is just the latest in a series of crackdowns on political and other human rights. If the country’s government does not step back from dismantling democratic rights the EU would be well advised to launch an investigation under the mechanisms provided for in the framework of the Everything But Arms agreement and to consider reviewing the trade preferences Cambodia enjoys.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I was very happy to hear about the release of Kem Sokha. For us to know that a political prisoner is out of arbitrary detention is always a relief. Although this development is positive, the situation in Cambodia is still extremely serious, given the gross disregard of its international human rights obligations and the serious attacks on democracy, namely the complete silencing of political opposition along with the broader climate of shrinking space for civil society. I’m particularly worried by the situation of human rights defenders, especially in light of the charges against five members of the Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association. As Europeans, we must always be aware of the violations conducted by our own companies in Cambodia. Attacks against indigenous peoples, including land-grabbing, affect many communities. It’s our responsibility to develop a trade policy that prevents corporations from harming these less developed countries and fragile states. Following the EU’s decision to suspend direct budget support to Cambodia, I wish to remind this House, and the EU in general, of the importance of dialogue and people—to—people contact in these contexts.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I welcome this new strong resolution against Prime Minister Hun Sen and his government’s repeated actions and violations of basic democratic principles. I want to welcome Sam Rainsy, a friend and a great leader, who does not give up in his struggle for more justice and democracy for the Cambodian people. The elections last July in Cambodia were a farce, the party of Hun Sen, in power for 33 years now, obtained 100% of all contested seats in the national assembly and the senate. The opposition was banned and declared illegal. The government of Hun Sen is illegitimate and I would like the EU and Ms Mogherini to recognise and acknowledge this fact. The EU gives a lot of money to Cambodia and we cannot continue doing business as usual. Cambodia benefits from the most favourable regime available under the US Generalized System of Preferences. Under Article 19 of this regulation, in case of serious human rights and labour rights violations the EU should suspend the preferential tariffs temporarily. If the EU wants to save its credibility we cannot do business as usual. I call on the Commission to publish immediately the conclusions of the last EU fact-finding missions and I invite the Commission to report these conclusions as soon as possible to Parliament.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, about forty days ago I was in Cambodia and documented and denounced the total absence of humanitarian rights in that country. And the Europe that weeps today, that tries to reflect on cambodian problems, has in reality been complicit and is complicit in this situation.  So, if Europe really wants to look at Cambodia and the issues and problems of the lack of humanitarian rights in South-East Asia, it must close those agreements, for example the EBA agreement, which, after eighteen years, has not brought any opportunity to the Cambodian peoples, but has even seriously damaged the country of Italy and our agriculture. That agreement must be closed, product invasions must be closed and stopped in order to prevent exploitation in Cambodia, to avoid killing the economy and the occupation of Italian rice and to avoid poisoning our tables as well.  This is something that should make us think: life expectancy in Cambodia is 64 years. We must not import this desperation into Europe, we must not import this issue into Italy, but we must deal with it, if anything, in Cambodia.  Mr President, I will end with a very quick appeal: I appeal to those who are today lacking precisely humanitarian rights in evicting a 90-year-old man named Grandfather Mariano in our country Italy.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Recent events in Cambodia, and above all the elections in which the ruling party received one hundred percent of the vote, or the dissolution of the opposition party clearly point to a very sad truth: Cambodia cannot be seen in terms of a democratic state. In this context, I believe that it is no longer enough to call on the Cambodian Government to respect democracy and respect the rule of law. In order to protect the Cambodian people from authoritarian rule and human rights violations, we need to reach for stronger measures. I therefore fully support the decision to withhold The European Union's assistance in support of the elections. In addition, I believe that consideration should be given to withdrawing trade preferences for Cambodia, as well as introducing visa restrictions for those responsible for human rights violations in cambodia.

name: Javier NART
text: – Mr President, we are condemning fraudulent elections and we are condemning human rights violations. In Cambodia President Hun Sen, a former Khmer Rouge, genocidal commander, and the president of the Cambodian People's Party. Where is the Cambodian People's Party incardinate? Oh, gee! He's incardinates at the International Democrat Center. And who's in the Central Democratic International? The European People's Party. So let's start at home. Out of coherence, out of decency, ethics and aesthetics, the first thing the European People's Party should do is to call for the expulsion of that indecent party with that indecent president who is Hun Sen. And one thing that is also up to us: it is not a question of suspending financial aid to fraudulent elections, which is enough, to say that they are unacceptable. What needs to be done is to suspend any aid to Cambodia that does not pass through credible international organizations. The rest is pure music, pure fanfare.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 10 September, Kem Sokha, leader of the Cambodian opposition, was released on bail on charges of treason despite enjoying parliamentary immunity and arbitrarily detained without trial for more than a year. Like him, many other political opponents, activists and journalists have come under the crosshairs of Hun Sen, the prime minister increasingly determined to extend his 33 years in power. In a seemingly democratic climate alone, Hun Sen's kleptocratic regime censored the network and gagged the press, dealing a blow to the last semblance of democracy with the farce of the last elections. What we must do, ladies and gentlemen, is to immediately suspend all aid which is not guaranteed by international organizations, and finally to take the decision to adopt a appropriate attitude towards these regimes which still have trade relations with us today, even at advantageous rates, without letting the selfish ambitions of a man ruin the dream and the need for democracy of the Cambodian citizens who are still coming out and healing the wounds of the terrible Khmer period. Red.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, thank you for the kind words you addressed to us earlier. After last year's Cambodian Supreme Court extinguished the CNRP, the opposing party that won 44% of the vote in the 2013 elections last year, to have detained its president and banned political activity to more than a hundred of its members, the 2018 elections for the Senate and Parliament were nothing more than a farce to allow Prime Minister Hun Sen's party to , in power since 1985, conquered all the places of these two organs of sovereignty and perpetuated himself in power. Madam High Representative, I have almost always praised your work but I must, in the case of Cambodia, tell you that the European Union, Cambodia's second trading partner, has been slow to react to the collapse of pluralism and democracy in that country and therefore can only apply individual sanctions to those responsible for this authoritarian drift and continue to maintain preferential trade agreements developed in the scheme of "everything but arms" with a regime that violates its obligations civil, political and labour rights of its citizens, including the Convention against Torture.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, for over three decades Cambodia has been ruled by an authoritarian leader, Hun Sen. Prime Minister Hun Sen and his party use violence, politically motivated prosecutions and widespread corruption to intimidate and suppress any kind of political opposition. Fear of losing the national elections in July 2018 prompted a major crackdown. The primary opposition, the Cambodia National Rescue Party, has been dissolved by the courts, with a leader, Sam Rainsy, forced into exile and another, Kem Sokha, jailed. The government restricts independent media and civil society groups through forced closures, threats, intimidation and arbitrary detention. I call on the Cambodian authorities to put end to all forms of harassment, abuse and politically motivated criminal charges against members of the political opposition, human rights defenders, trade unions, labour rights advocates and other civil society activists, and journalists of course. We need to use our diplomatic tools to protect the fundamental rights of Cambodian people to elect and to be elected, to guarantee pluralism and democratic principles.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the speed of the vertical collapse of democracy and fundamental rights in Cambodia is truly astonishing. In just one year, in fact, the only real opposition party, the Cambodia National Rescue Party, has been dissolved and its leader Kem Sokha has been imprisoned on false charges.  What reminds us of the slide towards a single party, the cult of the leader's personality, repression and obsession with any kind of opposition? It reminds me of Pol Pot and the terrible Khmer Rouge dictatorship, during which every single rule was aimed at destroying, torturing and rooting out anyone who was even suspected of not being aligned with the regime. Do we want to remember that Prime Minister Hun Sen and two senior officers are former members of the Khmer Rouge? How much difference do we find today between the Cambodian People's Party and Pol Pot's Communist Party of Kampuchea? The hunt for the dissident has remained practically the same. Historical memory is important so that history does not repeat, and Cambodia is in danger of this today.  I therefore call on the Commission to suspend with Cambodia the programme of preferential access to our single market and to make it conditional on respect for human and civil rights.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, last year saw significant steps backwards for Cambodia’s fragile democracy. One-party rule, authoritarian tendencies that have gained more ground in the country, and the space for political opposition and civil society has not so much shrunk as simply closed. At the general election in July following the enforced dissolution of the main opposition party, the ruling party won all seats in the National Assembly. The election took place in a highly restrictive environment and it was clearly not representative of the democratic will of the Cambodian citizens.
